PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Hamer) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiements involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators MacGibbon (from 241 citizens), Macklin (from 567 citizens) and Sheil (from 467 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Television, Illawarra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That a Government decision to force, at the expense of viewers, the transfer of WIN TV (and any future local broadcaster) from VHF to UHF transmission, while excluding Sydney metropolitan T.V. stations from this requirement, will place in jeopardy the future of the Illawarra and South Coast region's only local commercial T.V. operator.

Your petitioners request the Senate to protect the interests of the hundreds of thousands of television viewers within the area from Wollongong to the Victorian border served by WIN TV, by preventing the Government from taking this unwarranted and discriminatory action which disadvantages both viewers and advertisers on the South Coast to the benefit of the metropolitan networks.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Veterans' Entitlements Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Government did not honour its promise to consult with veterans before introducing the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should-
Oppose any sections of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill which would have the effect of reducing veterans' benefits and particularly that section which seeks to change the onus of proof.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Every citizen should have-
1. A constitutional guarantee of the right to vote and
2. A constitutional guarantee of the equality of votes.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should-Support the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) 1985 Bill
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telopea Park School Introductory English Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth express our concern at the possible relocation of the Telopea Park School Introductory English Centre, presently located at the corner of New South Wales Cresent and Manuka Circle in Barton, A.C.T. Such a move could only have detrimental educational and social consequences for the non-English speaking secondary students of the A.C.T.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will consider this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Sheikh Tajeddine Al-Hilaly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate will accept this petition to reverse the decision of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs the Honourable Chris Hurford to not permit a change of status to sheikh Tajeddine Al-Hilaly and to:

(a) Note the concern of us your petitioners that the Commonwealth Government chooses to decide who may be a fit and proper person to occupy the position of Imam of Lakemba Mosque by requiring that the sheikh depart by 30 September 1985 so that the position of Imam at the Mosque be left vacant to be filled by another person;

(b) Note your petitioners concern that this is a fundamental attack on the basic liberties of Australians being the right to believe and practice religious worship without interference and the right of our Imam to speak out against interference in religious worship by goverments (local or foreign) whenever he perceives it;
(c) Note that your petitioners request that permanent residence be granted to sheikh Tajeddine Al-Hilaly;

(d) Note that the discrimination thus perceived against sheikh Al-Hilaly be discontinued and that he be accorded respect and assistance given to all other religious leaders in Australia who have come from abroad.

We the undersigned petitioners state unreservedly our support for sheikh Al-Hilaly and our admiration for the manner in which he has performed his duties as Imam at a time when the Lebanese community has been strained by the tragic events in Lebanon. Furthermore his fraternal association with other religious leaders both christians and muslims has helped to prevent the disputes and divisions which presently exist in Lebanon from arising in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Belconnen Mall, Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
We the undersigned express our concern over the sale of the Belconnen Mall due to the likely detrimental effect on the provision of community facilities presently existing in the Belconnen Mall.

1. In particular we seek guarantees that the present Child Care Centre and Community Facilities be retained by incorporating the same into the conditions of sale of the Belconnen Mall and that the services will receive the same real level of funding and support currently provided by the Canberra Commercial Development Authority.

2. That a financial commitment to the building of Stage 4 of the Belconnen Mall listed under Section 14C in the Ordinance of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority be undertaken. Stage 4 to consist of Community Facilities such as Community Hall, large glassed enclosed community park, exhibition space, health and fitness club, ice rink, amusement centre and office accommodation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this petition be considered.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON VOLATILE SUBSTANCE FUMES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Volatile Substance Fumes.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

On behalf of the members of the Select Committee on Volatile Substance Fumes, I table the Committee's report on the health and social consequences of volatile substance abuse in Australia. The Committee was established in May 1984 at the initiative of Senator Bernie Kilgariff, and I believe we are indebted to Senator Kilgariff for bringing the Senate's attention to the need for this inquiry. It is certainly one of great concern to many people in Australia and, in particular, to many people in remote Aboriginal communities.

The Committee's terms of reference required it to consider two aspects of the phenomenon of volatile substance abuse: the intoxicating inhalation of a wide range of volatile substances by the cosmopolitan youth of urban areas (glue or solvent `sniffing'); and the use of petrol as an intoxicant by the youth of remote Aboriginal communities (`petrol sniffing').

In the second half of last year the Committee advertised its inquiry and sought information from people throughout Australia. Just over 100 submissions were received and, following a brief interruption due to the election at the end of last year, the Committee conducted an extensive program of public hearings, inspections and visits to remote Aboriginal communities. The Committee held 10 public hearings, covering all States except Tasmania, and visited Aboriginal communities in Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory.

The Committee collected a large amount of information, hitherto unassembled, and the length of the Committee's report reflects the fact that it is the first comprehensive report on the subject to be made in Australia.

In its report, the Committee concludes that concern about volatile substance abuse is justified, both in urban areas and in remote Aboriginal communities. The first reason for concern is that the practice of `sniffing' involves young people, generally between the ages of about 12 and 15, and in some instances, children younger than 10 are involved. The second reason for concern is that, in terms of accute and chronic physical and psychological effects, and the associated risk of `sudden sniffing death', the inhalation of volatile substances for the purpose of intoxication is highly dangerous. In remote Aboriginal communities there is a third major reason for concern, that the practice is of such prevalence that it is causing considerable social disruption and distress.

Because the two groups distinguished by the Committee's terms of reference are sociologically distinct, they have been considered separately, and the Committee's report has been presented in two parts. In the first part, the Committee concludes that volatile substance abuse is a widespread, though erratic problem-evidence from some areas having shown that experimentation may be as high as 50 per cent. There are three broad groups abusing volatile substances, experimenters, social abusers and chronic abusers, the latter of which form about 1 per cent of the total abuse population. While young people are generally aware of the practice, adults generally are not.

The Committee concludes that the primary causes of experimentation with volatile substances are curiosity and peer pressure; and facilitating factors include the wide availability of substances and the lack of preventative measures. The continued abuse of volatile substances appears to be due to the pleasurable effects of the practice, such as euphoria, excitement and group cohesion. In contrast, the primary cause of chronic abuse seems to be an inability to cope with seemingly intractable problems and, while social abusers do not come from any particular socio-economic or minority group, chronic abusers usually come from emotionally or economically deprived families.

In considering the responses to volatile substance abuse in urban areas, the Committee has made a number of conclusions and recom- mendations, the most important of which are as follows. Firstly, as a general conclusion, the Committee points out that the phenomenon of volatile substance abuse is a social problem not a `product' problem and it thus recommends that responses to the problem be directed towards preventing abuse through broadly based education programs.

More specifically, the Committee concludes that education is the best and most important strategy to prevent and reduce volatile substance abuse, although the Committee emphasises that no approach should provide specific information about the practice to young people. It recommends that Federal and State governments should adopt a preventative education strategy based on a dual approach of providing healthy lifestyle and personal development programs for adolescents, and providing factual information for parents and professional personnel. In this regard the Committee notes that the peer support program has the potential to play an extremely important role in the prevention of drug abuse and it recommends that the peer support foundation be supported financially by recurrent funding from both Federal and State grants.

The Committee has concluded that there is a small but significant need for treatment services for the rehabilitation of chronic sniffers. The concept of a national poisons informations centre is endorsed by the Committee, as is the concept of a national institute for drug and alcohol studies. The Committee recommends to the Federal Government that priority consideration be given to the establishment of such a centre.

The Committee also concludes that legislative action is not warranted, with three exceptions, the most important of which is that each State legislate to make it an offence for retailers knowingly to sell volatile substances to minors for the purpose of abuse. The Committee has also concluded that industry and government should co-ordinate an extensive campaign to educate retailers about the problems of volatile substance abuse and how they can assist to combat those problems.

The Committee also found that evidence in favour of dire warning labels outweighs evidence against them and recommends that industry continue progressively to identify and label products capable of abuse. The concept of industry sponsorship is supported by the Committee, which also recommends that a joint industry/government foundation be established in each State to co-ordinate and administer funding for action which is directed towards drug abuse prevention from industry groups.

In the second part of the report, the Committee has concluded that petrol sniffing is an Australia-wide phenomenon and that the magnitude of the problem is of sufficient proportion for urgent action to be taken. The Committee has thus recommended to Federal and State governments, and to Aboriginal agencies, that they give priority to all efforts to respond to the problem.

In examining the epidemiology of petrol sniffing the Committee has found that it is highly cyclic in prevalence, varying both regionally and temporarily. However, in some communities there is now a perennial core of chronic sniffers. Although a wide range of causes was proferred, the Committee was unable to get a clear indication as to why Aboriginal children sniffed petrol. The few sniffers that the Committee spoke with unanimously said it was for `fun'. The causes most frequently cited by adults were peer pressure, curiosity and boredom. Factors contributing to the continuation of the problem were found to be lack of community resources, lack of strong leadership and effective decision-making processes, lack of commitment to solve the problem and lack of co-ordination by controlling instrumentalities. The problem of petrol sniffing was also seen by some to be a symptom of the many broader social problems besetting Aboriginal people in remote communities.

The acute and chronic physical effects of petrol inhalation were found to be similar to those induced by most other volatile substances with the addition of the toxic effects of organic lead, which primarily affects liver and kidney function, causes reversible and irreversible brain damage and damages peripheral nerves. Some sniffers have already been found to have chronic lead poisoning.

Numerous responses to petrol sniffing have been made, including punishment, exile, locking up of petrol supplies and vehicles, and the provision of recreation facilities and youth workers, but nowhere did the Committee find complete success.

In making recommendations the Committee has suggested, firstly, that the act of petrol sniffing not be made a criminal offence, but that the acts of supplying or inciting minors to inhale petrol be made offences. Secondly, in order to control petrol sniffing, that ring- leaders who pressure children to sniff be removed from communities. To do this, care and custody provisions of State child welfare legislation could be used. Thirdly, the Committee has recommended that there is a need for education of parents and other adult groups as to the consequences to the health of children who inhale petrol. Fourthly, the Committee has found that there is an urgent need for the training of Aboriginal youth workers and recreation officers to work in communities. Finally, the Committee believes that the solution which has the greatest chance of solving the problem in the long term is the homelands/outstations movement and the Committee has thus recommended that outstations be given far greater support than they are currently accorded.

In suggesting a strategy for the control of petrol sniffing, the Committee points out that all actions must originate from and be controlled by the Aboriginal people in those communities concerned and that all programs created to prevent or reduce petrol sniffing should be based on the involvement of all youth in both recreational and educational activities.

In concluding my tabling statement, I would like to thank all those who have been involved in the Committee's inquiry; the people who made submissions and gave evidence and, in particular those who assisted with the Committee's visits to remote areas. I would also like to thank the various Hansard officers who accompanied the Committee on its visits to remote areas.

I would also like to thank, on behalf of the Committee, the members of the committee's secretariat; the Secretary, Dr Pippa Carron, research officers, Mr Toby Miller and Mr Greg Rillen, and the steno-secretary, Mrs Jean Thompson, for their outstanding work in assisting to collect and bring together the large amount of information which has formed the committee's report.
Finally, I personally would like to thank the other members of the Committee for their support in producing a unanimous report on this very vexing issue.
I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM REVENUE BILL 1985EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has commenced debate on the Petroleum Revenue Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) which are clearly related to each other and are being dealt with cognately. I commenced my speech by making some general observations about the Government's policy in relation to the petroleum industry and, in particular, to its proposals for a resource rent tax regime to apply, although at present its policy is related only to Greenfields off-shore areas. There is, of course, an in-principle commitment to this form of taxation which the industry and we in the Opposition are concerned may be applied progressively by the Government not only to the petroleum industry but also perhaps to the whole of the mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The other worrying aspect of the Government's proposals for a resource rent tax is the fact that it is to take effect from 1 July 1984-and here we are at the end of 1985 and the Government still has not produced even a draft or exposure draft of legislation for such an important new tax. It seems as though that is not likely to be seen for some time. Yet the Government is proceeding to seek cash bids for new and highly prospective off-shore areas for exploration for oil and gas. There is not only no sign yet of a capital gains tax and how that will apply but no sign of the resource rent tax either. How anybody can make any sensible bids in that state of the law I do not know, but perhaps the Government will be able to tell us that in due course, though I very much doubt it.

This legislation is a dry drum, so to speak, for the Government's attachment to a resource rent form of taxation. Nevertheless, the Opposition will not oppose this measure because it could have some benefit for some producers or explorers. Its framework has been explained by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). It is called resource rent royalty legislation-RRR legislation rather than RRT-but its immediate purpose is to give full legislative effect to an agreement which has been entered into by the Western Australian Government West Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd-Wapet- which is the owner and operator of the Barrow Island oil field amongst others. It is classified as an on-shore operation. It is an island off Western Australia, but it is part of Western Australia so it is an on-shore oil field. In fact, it is a very old oil field and the purpose of this legislation is to encourage the company to continue producing oil from the field which is becoming quite depleted. It would not be economic for the company to proceed much longer with the extraction of the oil that is there, under the existing tax regime with the full effect of the crude oil levy by the Commonwealth and the royalty to the State.

The agreement was entered into on 25 June and took effect on 1 July this year. Legislation has been passed by the Western Australian Parliament and this legislation is required at Federal level because there has to be a new taxing regime. The existing crude oil levy arrangements have to be modified as do State royalties. That is the purpose of this legislation. It will have a beneficial effect in relation to Wapet, and it may have a beneficial effect in other special cases involving oil fields around Australia. It is for the companies concerned to consider whether they want to make use of it. The Opposition is not opposed to this legislation. I emphasise that that does not affect our opposition to and great concern about the proposed resources rent tax, as a sword of Damocles which hangs over the whole petroleum industry and ultimately, I fear, may hang over the mining industry as well. The real concern about that related to the proclivities of this Government in the tax field. If there were some other and more beneficial tax regime to be substituted, of course, neither the industry nor the Opposition would be quite so worried about it. The fact of this is seen as an additional or in effect, excess profits tax is the really worrying aspect of the resource rent tax proposals. I think that concern is well justified when one considers the extent to which this Government has created new imposts on the oil industry. For instance, in March 1983 when this Government was elected the situation in relation to taxing the oil or gas industry was that we had the old oil excise or the crude oil levy-we are dealing with this today in reapplying the levy-there were of course Federal and State royalities on production, the Federal excise and State franchise on petroleum products and some production licence arrangements.

Now in December 1985 and post-March 1983 we have the following tax regime relating to the industry: We have taxes on old, intermediate and new oil. Admittedly the intermediate oil tax is some alleviation for the industry, particularly in Bass Strait. However, there is now a new oil excise whereas previously there was no tax on what is classified as new oil until this Government came to power. There is now a proposed resource rent tax. There is now cash bonus bidding which has been introduced and which, in effect, is another tax impost on the industry. That may be with or without a resources rent tax, we will not know whether this is so until we see the full details of the lagislation. We have production licence arrangements such as Federal and State royalties on production. We have retention lease arrangements which involve a licence fee and a threat of higher premiums. Of course, we have an increased Federal excise on petroleum as well as the State franchise fees on petroleum profits. Incidentally in regard to the Federal excise, despite Mr Hawke's promises in 1983 that there would be a reduction of 3c a litre in the price of petrol in fact there has been an impost of more than 3c a litre on the consumer of petroleum products. We have had various threats from the Government about signature bonus payments and, as I have said, retention lease premiums. Of course, goodness knows what is in store in relation to production in the Timor Sea and even perhaps a hydrocarbons corporation.

That is the sad picture which emerges at the end of nearly three years of this Government's dealings with the vital petroleum industry. No wonder there is widespread concern in the industry because it does not know where it stands. The industry does not know what is in store for it next. This in an industry absolutely vital to Australia's future and which has an absolute priority for finding more oil in particular and gas as well. As I said we in the Opposition are very concerned. We have to see this legislation, although we are not opposing it, in the context of the attitude of this Government to this vital industry. I want to emphasise that the only reason we are going along with this legislation, as indeed Wapet itself has emphasised in discussions I have had with it, is that this is simply a tax on old oil. If it were a tax on any new oil that of course would be completely in breach of the incentives and encouragements given to the industry to explore for oil in recent years-most of which of course is now unfortunately under a cloud as a result of this Government's taxing policies.

There are a few comments I wish to make on the nature of this legislation. Despite the fact that the agreement was entered into between the Western Australian Government and Wapet in June this year, the legislation did not come into this place until fairly late in the session. Even after its introduction the Government had to move 41 amendments during the Committee stage in the House of Representatives. It did this, incidentally, without giving any notice to the Opposition at all. The amendments were simply bunged down on the table only during the Committee stage of the debate, not even at the beginning of the debate on the Bill. Although these amendments were minor, they indicated very inadequate preparation, poor drafting and a general lack of consultation and liaison with everyone concerned.

There are still anomalies in the present amendments and of particular concern is new clause 2A in the Schedule to the Petroleum Revenue Bill, which introduces a penalty by way of additional royalty under the agreement. It is not stated in the Bill, but this penalty appears to apply to cases where a producer is in breach of the agreement. We are concerned that the terms of that breach and the level of penalty are not stipulated, nor are there any consultative arrangements in place apparently, by which appeals may be made or further negotiations conducted. The Government has also introduced an amendment to remove the ability of a party to the agreement to terminate the agreement after seven days notice in writing. These are some of the confusing situations that still occur.

There is also the remaining concern that Wapet has about this matter. Wapet still has to sign the agreement and it really needs some guidance from the Federal Government before it goes about one particular situation. There is a difference between the agreement made between Wapet and the Western Australian Government and the model agreement which the Government says should apply to any special arrangements of this kind-and this applies to Wapet as much as any other interested oil producer who wants to take advantage, if such there be, of this legislation. There is a difference between the actual pioneer agreement between Wapet and the Western Australian Government and the scheduled agreement in this Bill. The Schedule details definitions of what is meant by `an arms length transaction', whereas the Wapet agreement with the Western Australian Government does not contain that sort of detail. In fact, it may well be and probably is a fact that on a literal interpretation of this Bill, this Federal legislation would not apply to the very Bill that has been the cause of all the legislation here and in Western Australia. I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans to indicate whether the State agreement with Wapet will be regarded as valid in accordance with this Federal legislation. Also, there is another clause in this Bill which seems to limit the power of State Ministers to make decisions which are not in accordance with procedures approved by the Federal Minister and presumably that gives the Federal Government total power of veto over the States.

The arrangements between Western Australia and the Commonwealth are for a sharing of the revenue that is raised by this Bill and presumably there is agreement on that score between the Commonwealth and the State. That is not a matter on which I really want to comment except to say that the Commonwealth will be paying Western Australia about $20m this year in recognition of or compensation for loss of revenue to the State as a result of its giving up its royalties which it would have received had the old arrangements continued-that is assuming, of course, that Wapet continued in production. That seems to be a bit of a bonus for Western Australia and I suppose it is justified.

As I have said, this legislation applies only to Barrow Island at this stage. However, apparently discussions are being carried on with the respective State governments and the Federal Government about other potential candidates. Fortunately the industry itself will still be able to choose whether it will come under the umbrella of this legislation or whether it will carry on with the existing tax arrangements. There may be some inducement for some alleviation of the effect of the impost on old oil, particularly when oil fields are depleted.

I hope that the Federal Government does not seek to promote this legislation as a dry run, so to speak, for its resource rent tax before it exposes the RRT legislation. There is a desperate need for this Government to put down an exposure draft of its resource rent tax legislation. Is that too much to hope for particularly in view of the fact that the legislation will apply retrospectively to 1 July 1984-that is, 18 months ago. However, this Government has not been able to produce even an exposure draft of the legislation. If the Government seriously intends to go on with this alternative tax regime, is it not reasonable that everybody should know, and know soon, just what the exact details are? Major decisions are having to be made by people in the industry on matters which are absolutely vital to the future economic health of this nation. We are entitled to expect far better than that from this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Petroleum Revenue Bill 1985 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. Listening to Senator Durack say that the Opposition is not opposing this legislation reminds me that after the election of 1974 Billy Snedden, the then Leader of the Opposition, described the outcome as one in which the Opposition did not lose the election-it was just that it did not win it. It seems to me that that type of thinking is being applied in respect of the Petroleum Revenue Bill. Although the Opposition is not opposing the Bill, it has not gone quite as far as saying that it actually supports it. One cannot be sure whether in fact Senator Durack's supporting argument to the head statement that the Opposition is not opposing the legislation was in fact opposition in support. Senator Durack's speech was certainly an excursion into a wide ranging area of Opposition concerns about tax. However, he did not seem to say very much about the legislation.
—The legislation is all about tax.

—Yes, but the honourable senator talked about the tax package and what this Government is doing. He said that at last the Government had the courage to address the major taxing problems of this nation. However, he did so in such a confused way that I do not think anyone listening to the debate quite understood what the point of his opposition was.
—That's not unusual.

—No, it is not unusual. This legislation seeks to replace crude oil excise levies and to rationalise the present taxing regimes with a resource rental royalty. It is proposed that a tax based on an oil resource rental tax will replace the ad valorem tax that applies at present. This legislation, which recognises Western Australian legislation, has been jointly worked out between the Commonwealth and the State of Western Australia. West Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd, or Wapet, which operates at Barrow Island in the north-west of Western Australia, is party to, agrees with and supports this legislation. So it is legislation that has consensus support. It is also legislation which fits into the mosaic of this Government's approach to the proper taxing policies with respect to resource development in the petroleum area.

SPEECH.PARA: When debating matters of this sort, I always like to point out that the petroleum resources of the nation are the property of the people held in trust by the Government which gives licence to develop by private companies. Therefore, it is proper that there be a payment of royalty or tax which rewards the public purse in some way when the exploitation of those resources is undertaken. On this occasion, what we have done is merely rationalise the existing structure. It is the on-land application, if you like, of resource rent tax and that tax applies above a threshold which is calculated by taking the long term bond rate, adding 15 per cent and then taxing anything above that at the rate of 40 per cent. While in some sense the actual details of the application fo resource rental tax are still to be refined, in this case that is the formula that will be followed.

This legislation also sits easily and compatibly with this Government's cash bidding legislation. Now we have legislation covering the letting out of off-shore exploration leases, legislation has been announced and is in prospect for resource rental tax, and we have the resource rental royalties regime as well, and that brings all those items together.

Given that Senator Durack has taken a long time in speaking in this debate, although his Party supports the legislation, it remains for me to say only that it is a commendable initiative of the Western Australian Government and of the Western Australian Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr David Parker, in working with the Commonwealth to bring this legislation to this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a triumph for co-operative federalism.

—Yes, it is a triumph for co-operative federalism, as the Minister says. It stands as a model, which, I believe, other States will eventually follow so that, even within the federal system in Australia, we will have a completely rational way of dealing with taxes on petroleum production. Commendation of the Western Australia Government's approach, and particularly of the Minister, David Parker, in its discussions with the Commonwealth should be noted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack, in his remarks, said that the return to the State is estimated to be in the order of $20m. He came perilously close to criticising that gain for Western Australia. Of course, he did not do it finally. Senator Durack's constituency being Western Australia may have hindered his making the criticism that some of his colleagues from the House of Representatives made of that type of gain to the State. It reflects well on the Government of Western Australia that it has taken this initiative. The outcome will be beneficial. It will help the State Government and it will bring on at Barrow Island more productively a resource which is awaiting this legislation going through to be further exploited. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Revenue Bill is supported by the Australian Democrats. It permits the waiving of State royalties and Commonwealth excise duties when a State government introduces a resource rent tax and signs a revenue sharing agreement with the Commonwealth. It seems to me that the chief advantage of this Bill is that it will mean that older fields can continue to be developed productively. Our oil resource is variable, depending on how much of a field we can economically produce. If we are interested in oil self-sufficiency, it makes good sense to create an economic regime which encourages people actually to produce as much oil as possible from a field and not just to abandon it when it still has 20 or 30 per cent of its producible reserve. This Bill provides for that. I think it is a good Bill in that respect and it is a good Bill for the conservation and wise use of the resource.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also a good Bill because it advances the concept of resource rental taxation. I believe this shows a coming of age in Australia. Australia is making a transition from a Third World country, which simply considered itself an open quarry for anyone who wanted to come along to exploit it, to a developed country, a country with some self-confidence that can say: `Our resource is worth something and you will have to pay for it if you want it. We will not just give it to you'. This is a very important point. As honourable senators may or may not have noted, I come from overseas and I have a slightly different perspective on the way multinationals work and also on how Australia perceives its own resources. It seems to me that Australians have very little true appreciation of the value of their land, their trees, or their resources in general. I suppose this is only natural because for so many years we were simply a colony of a very important and aggressive nation, Great Britain, which used us to supply raw materials for its manufacturing processes.

This thinking goes on today. It is a kind of parallel to the New Guinea cargo cult of some years past where the New Guinea natives, perceiving that aeroplanes would land at Port Moresby with refrigerators and washing machines on board, would go out in the bush, hack out a strip, build a decoy aeroplane out of palm thatch, and hope somehow to attract the cargo from the sky. I think Australian leaders often do the same thing. We put in massive infrastructure development, hoping that somebody will come along and use it to mine our resources. We can develop our own resources. We should have the self-confidence to do so, and I think the self-confidence is coming.

The Australian view towards the country is really a function of the people who came here first, the convicts and settlers, who were ripped out of a Northern Hemisphere environment and put in a very harsh, to them, area to which they simply could not relate. When I came to Australia from the Northern Hemisphere I found it difficult to appreciate the land. It was harsh; the seasons were backwards; Christmas came at the wrong time of the year; the weather patterns were wrong. If one projects that back to the early settlers, who depended on their senses, one can see that they may have had an intense dislike for the land, especially if they were kept here under force. I hope that modern Australians can learn to appreciate their land, and when it is exploited to extract the proper value from it.

I agree with Senator Cook that the resources of the nation belong to the nation, not to the multinational oil companies or to any individual. If they are to be utilised-I hope not overutilised-the people of this nation should receive recompense and share in the benefits. It should not be for just one small section of the community, namely, the oil companies and those who support them, it should be for everyone. For those reasons I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the support of the Senate for this measure, even though it was not given very generously or graciously in the case of Senator Durack. Senator Durack seems generally to have failed to appreciate the significance of the legislation. It is not just another taxing measure or impost, but rather a very serious and major attempt to rationalise State and Federal tax regimes in this area and to do so in a way, as Senator Sanders said in his very admirable contribution, that is very much in the interests both of the companies involved in these projects and of the nation, to the extent that it will encourage more production from marginal oil fields than would otherwise be the case. That is the essential virtue of a resource rent royalty or resource rent tax approach. That is why so much effort has been expended, in co-operation with the Western Australian Government in particular so far, to devise this tax regime.

SPEECH.PARA: The Petroleum Revenue Bill is of general application, as it has to be for constitutional reasons, quite apart from anything else. As has been made clear throughout this debate, the Bill's immediate application is to Western Australia and in particular the Barrow Island field. The Schedules to the Bill were being written at the same time as the agreement between Western Australia and West Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd was being negotiated. That very tight timetable was made necessary by the requirement to get the legislation through the Western Australian Parliament before it rose, for a number of months, and through the Commonwealth Parliament before it rose. That is why a number of amendments to the legislation, especially to Schedule 1, were made in the House of Representatives after the Bill was originally introduced. The need for those amendments was not a product of the Bill being in any way ill-thought out, as Senator Durack was suggesting, or of there being a lack of consultation, as he was also suggesting, but rather of the circumstances that I have just described.

A question has arisen as to whether, in the particular case of Barrow Island, the legislation as it is now before us is, in fact, in conformity with the agreement that has been negotiated between Western Australia and Wapet and endorsed by the Western Australian Parliament. A question has been raised by Senator Durack as to whether, in particular, there is that conformity insofar as the Western Australian agreement does not specifically go to the extent of defining an `arm's length' transaction, even though it provides, as is required by the Schedule, that where the relevant petroleum is sold by the producer otherwise than in an arm's length transaction, the producer shall be taken to have sold the petroleum for an amount equal to the value of the petroleum at the time of the sale.

Let me say for the record, as invited to by Senator Durack, that I am of the considered view that the agreement is so clearly written in accordance with the requirements of Schedule 1 and so obviously written with the intention of conforming to Schedule 1 that the omission of a definition of the expression `arm's length' is a purely formal matter and of no substantive significance whatsoever. Clearly, it is the case that the agreement conforms with all the essential requirements of the Bill. Nonetheless, out of an abundance of caution it may well be appropriate that at some time in the future the agreement between Western Australia and Wapet be formally amended to embody the definition in question. I will suggest to the Western Australian Government and Wapet that at an appropriate time-perhaps after the Western Australian Parliament resumes next year-such an agreed formal amendment be made. I stress that I do not believe that such an amendment is necessary, but it may, nevertheless, be useful to put the matter beyond any possible shadow of a doubt.

Let me say finally that this is an important, in fact path-breaking, piece of legislation, as will be the off-shore resource rent tax legislation when we introduce and enact it next year, legislation which will, in fact, largely mirror, in its substantive provisions, the provisions of the Western Australian resource rent royalty legislation which has been passed by the Western Australian Government to complement the Bills before us today. There has been some criticism by the Opposition of the passage of time that will occur before the RRT legislation finally sees the light of day. I acknowledge that it is important for that legislation to be formally enacted as soon as possible, but I think it should be pointed out for the record that the problem has been the enormous workload placed on the Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office in the last few months as a result of this year's tax reform package. I make the point that the only project development to which that off-shore RRT regime is presently applicable is the Jabiru project. I assure the Senate that that project has not been in any way inhibited from proceeding by the delay in formally enacting the legislation. All outstanding policy issues so far as that legislation is concerned have been resolved and publicly announced, certainly to the satisfaction of the Jabiru project people, and no doubt also to the satisfaction of any oil company or potential investor who wants to know what the parameters of the RRT regime will be. So, although it is no doubt a good debating point on occasions like this to make the sorts of points that Senate Durack has made, I assure him and the Senate that there is no cause for any criticism of the Government in the way that this has operated so far. I commend the Bills to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment, requests or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Customs Tariff (Stand-by Duty) Bill 1985 is to impose a special customs duty of 3c per litre or about $5 per barrel on crude oil imports by local refiners who do not pick up their allocation of Australian crude oil under that voluntary allocation scheme. This may appear to be a genuine attempt by the Government to guarantee the future of the Australian oil industry, but in fact when we look at it this is measure which is really designed to lead to further govenrment control and an increased tax burden on an industry already overwhelmed by government controls and taxes. I have already had something to say in detail about that earlier and I do not propose to repeat it now.

SPEECH.PARA: The only real purpose of this Bill is to secure such government control over oil production and maintain its already bloated crude oil levy on old, intermediate and what is now new oil as well. The Opposition will oppose this short-sighted and unnecessary legislation. We will vote against it. It is interesting to note that the Bill was initially introduced into this Parliament in May 1984 by the predecessor to the present Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. However, there was a storm of criticism of it within the industry and I think the Bill was withdrawn. It was not proceeded with and presumably it disappeared with the election at the end of the year. It may be that the Government has made some concessions to meet the criticisms of it, but the general principle of the legislation remains unchanged. Perhaps the Minister can tell us whether he has had any genuine consultation with industry about the matter, but the impression I have is that there has not. Nor does the Bill reveal any great indication of that. Maybe it is just another indication of Senator Evans's penchant for fixing everything up by passing laws through this Parliament in the belief that that somehow does so.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were never guilty of that sin.

—No. I had a little more judgment, I think, about these matters than he has. I think his predecessor had perhaps a little more judgment than he has about the virtue of legislation and the role of lawyers-which is an every increasing one, of course, if Senator Evans had his way. This legislation is contrary to the spirit of the voluntary allocation arrangements and it is contrary to other measures to deregulate the crude oil market, particularly since longer term exports have been permitted in the current year.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is also inequitable in that there are no other controls over fuel imports and the duty would not apply to, say, the importation by independent retailers. Refiners have had an incentive not to pick up locally produced oil during the market downturn and following the depreciation of the dollar, both of which were thought to be providing a threat to the local industry, but that threat has not been of any significance. While some refiners have sought a reduction in crude oil allocation levels, the industry still substantially accords with the voluntary arrangements and, in fact, producers have increased production to take advantage of the export opportunities which they have been given. Government revenue has substantially increased as a result of the export of oil and increased production. There has been an extra $507m in the 1984-85 Budget revenue and a further increase of about $300m is forecast for the current Budget year.

The Government has been having a financial bonanza from its taxes on oil production in this country, yet here we have a measure designed by the Government to increase its revenue further. The Government estimates that the proposed duty would raise $4m each month in which any one medium sized refiner remained in a shortfall or underlift situation. I believe that that would be justified only if there had been a collapse in existing voluntary arrangements.

This legislation is contrary to the Opposition's deregulatory stance. It makes a mockery of the rhetoric from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about deregulation. I do not think that I can accuse Senator Gareth Evans of being an enthusiast for deregulation on the basis of his record as Minister for Resources and Energy, but we hear a lot of empty rhetoric from the Prime Minister about deregulation. Yet in this measure the Government proposes further regulation and taxes for an industry already, as I said, overwhelmed by such imposts. For those reasons the Opposition will oppose what we can only see as a draconian measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not see the Customs Tariff (Stand-By Duty) Bill as a draconian measure at all and we are, indeed, supporting this Bill. We support it because we see it as a necessary measure to protect the partial allocation scheme. Under the partial allocation scheme most new oil lifted in Australia is available for sale on the free market, and old oil from which the Government receives about 71 per cent of the price per barrel is sold under the allocation system. Under existing legislation it would in some circumstances be cheaper to purchase crude oil overseas at spot prices rather than lift the full allocation of Australian crude oil. This would result in avoidance of the old oil excise and a subsequent drop in government income. By providing that an excise of 3c per litre be paid on imported oil substituted for Australian crude, government income-public income-is protected. I should think that that would interest Senator Durack but apparently it does not. For this reason alone we support the Bill. I do not wish to delay the Senate any longer. I indicate that we will vote with the Government on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Sanders for his support for the Customs Tariff (Stand-By Duty) Bill and I have noted Senator Durack's comments on behalf of the Opposition. I simply say in reply that the purpose of this Bill is to maintain some control, as Senator Durack says, of crude oil production and distribution in this country. But we are seeking to do that not because of any passionate commitment to heavy-handed government regulation and intervention for its own sake, but rather in the interests of maintaining, as Senator Sanders says, the integrity and credibility of the present allocation system. I will be happy to publicly debate at any time the merits of that system, but I will spare the Senate that contribution in view of the shortage of time with which we are confronted today.

SPEECH.PARA: I say finally that this Bill has been substantially redrafted following its initial exposure in 1984, to meet criticisms from various industry quarters. Those criticisms have largely subsided as a result of the reconsideration which then took place. Since Senator Durack expressed so much confidence in my predecessor's judgment in legislative matters, I am happy to inform him that, in fact, the present legislation was settled by my predecessor. The only reason it was not proceeded with late last year is that we ran out of time after the reconsideration process had taken place. The only reason it was not proceeded with in the first half of this year is that it was caught up in the May-June review of the allocation and import parity pricing system that then took place. We believe that so long as the present partial allocation system remains, it is important to have in place the kind of penalty duty regime for which this Bill provides as a guarantee that the integrity of that system will be preserved. Accordingly, I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 November, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of the Opposition on the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. This Bill seeks in essence to do three things. It seeks to restore to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in two instances certain powers lost by the Tribunal as a result of two court cases and to increase the disciplinary powers the Tribunal has over individual broadcasters. Before going on the three specific areas of the Bill, I think it appropriate to note that this Bill is the second piece of broadcasting legislation to come before the Parliament in the course of a couple of weeks. That is indicative of the way in which the Government is dealing with broadcasting legislation-by making piecemeal adjustments to one of the most complicated pieces of legislation this Parliament has ever passed. It is now evident that the whole regime of the Broadcasting and Television Act is in need of fundamental overhaul and revision. The Government must at some stage turn its attention to dealing with questions of a far broader scope rather than what it is doing at the moment, which is making piecemeal adjustments on the run.

SPEECH.PARA: The second general point I make is that this Bill goes largely to the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. We did not have a chance to debate the annual report of the Broadcasting Tribunal this year. Therefore, let me take this opportunity to note that Mr David Jones, the Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal, reaches the end of his term at the end of this year. He is taking an appointment, as I understand it, as a County Court judge in Victoria. I think all honourable senators would wish to be associated with congratulating Mr Jones on having steered the Broadcasting Tribunal through a number of very difficult cases and through a very difficult period in the history of broadcasting regulation in Australia. Mr Jones has done an excellent job as Chairman of the Tribunal and deserves to be congratulated.

This legislation touches on three issues. First, it touches on the right of the Broadcasting Tribunal to determine standards relative to the broadcasting of programs for children. Secondly, it touches upon the power of the Tribunal to regulate the quota of Australian material in advertisements. Finally, it deals with disciplinary powers of the Tribunal under section 119 of the Act. I shall take each of those issues in turn. The powers of the Tribunal to establish standards for the broadcasting of children's programs came from a long and complicated case before the High court of Australia in May 1985. On 21 May the Full Bench of the High Court rendered its judgment in the case Herald-Sun Television Pty Ltd. and others v. the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. In effect, the Court struck down the powers of the Broadcasting Tribunal to pre-classify children's television programs; that is, the requirement that all programs broadcast for children in the designated C category and in designated hours for children's television be classified by the Tribunal before they go to air. The Court said in its judgment:

. . . only programs which meet the standards determined for children's programs should be televised within particular hours . . . The Act does not go further and give the Tribunal power to decide that a particular program should not be shown during those hours . . . The Act does not give the Tribunal power to give directions for the purpose of enforcing standards which have already been laid down, or for the purpose of substituting its judgment in a particular case for the application of a pre-determined standard.

The judgment noted that the Tribunal had been relying upon various censorship powers and held that the Act did not permit the Tribunal to so rely. As a result of that case there was a great deal of confusion about the powers of the Tribunal in relation to the control and pre-classification of children's television. This concerned the Department of Communications. It received a submission from the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations dealing with this matter in August 1985. The relevant part of the FACTS submission is fairly short. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
FACTS submission to Department of Communications, August 1985
Pre-classification precludes ascertainment.

(e) It is no answer to say that the classification only relates to material which is to be televised for one hour in any day. In fact children's programs are extremely costly with no corresponding financial benefit to the station. The rejection of a program by pre-classification will, in most cases, mean that the program will not be produced at all. This deprives the viewing audience of some potentially excellent programs which have, in effect, been ``censored''. Further, pre-classification automatically prohibits `live' programming and therefore limits the potential of developing certain types of programs, e.g., news, sport, current affairs, designed for children. It is now also proposed that ``programs which are advertised or presented in a way which suggests they meet the ``C'' conditions relating to content'' will also be subject to pre-classification. FACTS is unsure as to what this means. On any interpretation it goes well beyond the power the Tribunal previously purported to apply.

(f) The system of pre-classification is likely to produce sterotyped programs which are known or thought to appeal to the predilections of the Classification Committee. Over a period of time this will produce stagnant and unimaginative television programs and therefore stifle creativity.

(g) The proposal will effectively deny licensees from any right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal when it is alleged that a program does not comply with the Standard. This right is now enshrined in the Act and should not be taken away.

(h) It is argued that the production of Australian drama for children will be adversely affected if there is no pre-classification of programs. This argument cannot be sustained. The pre-classification of programs can have no effect on the amount of first release children's drama telecast each year by licenses. In the absence of pre-classification, licensees would continue to be required to telecast a prescribed amount of Australian produced children's drama which complies with criteria established by the Tribunal. There is ample evidence to show that since the High Court decision on pre-classification, licensees have continued to commission and purchase new children's drama.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In essence, FACTS was saying that its principal concern about this matter was that it was a very costly procedure. Secondly, it was worried that the pre-classification of programs meant that children were being denied access to live television broadcasts and that, obviously, because a program could not be pre-classified and at the same time be a live broadcast, children were being fed a diet of rather standardised, formalised, stereotyped television programs and that the excitment of live sport, news broadcasts or any sort of live entertainment relevant to children was being denied to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter further came before the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which, in reporting on its examination of annual reports, published its third report on children's television standards in August 1985. The Senate Committee undertook a lengthy investigation of this matter and came up with a series of recommendations which, in effect, said that the power of pre-classification should be returned to the Tribunal and made explicit in legislation. The Government has proceeded to take up the recommendations of the Committee. It is a further example of the value of the Senate committee system in dealing with a specific matter coming before the notice of the legislature as a result of some doubts about the existence of powers under Commonwealth legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fine committee too.

—Senator Colston says that it is a fine committee. I note that Senator Colston and Senator Teague, who were intimately concerned with that investigation, are in the chamber this morning. That determination by the Government has received a great deal of support. For instance, it has received support from the Australian Children's Television Foundation. In fact the front cover of its annual report for 1984-85 draws attention to this matter. The front cover has a drawing of a large number of small furry animals in deep distress over the fact that a newspaper headline indicates: Court `pulls plug on children's television'. The back cover has the same furry animals in a state of high excitement over the headline: `Government restores Tribunal's powers'. I think that is a little exaggerated, if I may say so. I think the Australian Children's Television Foundation is also starting to intrude a little too far into the general question of automatically knowing what is best for children.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless the Opposition is happy to support the amendments to be made to that section of the Act. In particular we are happy that certain progress has been made towards overcoming our problem about live broadcasts for children. In the House of Representatives our shadow Minister for Communications, Mr Ian Macphee, pressed the Government very strongly on whether the new regime would allow the classification of material for children's television at the script stage. Previously, this material has had to be actually produced ready for broadcast and then classified. We have been pressing that what should happen is that a classification should be given for a script and, if the script receives the classification, the program can go ahead and be made and could well turn to be a live program, of course adhering to the script which had been approved. Mr Macphee pressed this very strongly in the House of Representatives on 19 November and, in replying to the debate, Mr Duffy, the Minister for Communications, agreed with the point Mr Macphee was making. In Hansard of 19 November he said that all of his officers `are clearly of the view that the Bill as currently drafted would allow the making of a standard requiring pre-classification at the script stage'. He went on to say:

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is to examine the desirability of making a standard which will allow approval for children's television programs to be based on the script for the program rather than the completed program.
We very much welcome the Minister's assurance, and I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief statement made by Mr Macphee in response to the Minister's assurances given in the House.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
OPPOSITION VICTORY ON CHILDREN'S TV CLASSIFICATION
The Opposition has successfully pressured the Government into agreeing that children's television programs may be approved at the script stage, rather than only when the program is completed.
This is a major victory for the film and television industries, and will open the way for C classified programs to be broadcast live.

The Shadow Minister for Communications, Mr Ian Macphee, strongly supported the Film Industry Standing Committee, which called for the C classification to be available at the final script stage and not merely at the program stage.
``Not to accept the Committee's approach might result in some excellent scripts never being presented as programs because of the possibility of being denied a C status,'' he told the Parliament.

``If the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal can make a judgment at the script stage and grant a final C certificate, that will encourage more investment and encourage more commitment on the part of writers, producers and actors to produce high quality children's programs. We hope that this flexibility will also mean that programs can be run live. As it now is, they are all pre-recorded.

``As a matter of principle the Opposition is opposed to the concept of censorship. But after due deliberation we accept the need for prior approval of programs in order that they be given the C classification to show that they are designed especially for children.
``The Opposition is quite adamant about the fact that this is the only type of pre-classification which is tolerable and, even then, it ought not necessarily be continued in perpetuity.''
Mr Macphee also criticised the trend towards increased regulation, legal complexity and cost of proceedings before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

``The Opposition believes very strongly in self regulation in the broadcasting industry, and we take the view that those broadcasting standards which a government considers to be important should be in the Act itself rather than drawn up as regulations and administered by the Tribunal,'' he said.

``I intend preparing on behalf of the Opposition a policy aimed at greatly reducing the regulations imposed by the Parliament and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on the broadcasting industry. Moreover we are determined to remove the potential for abuse in procedures designed to help the public. Commercial broadcasting management should have the primary responsibility for meeting and enforcing standards, with the Tribunal retaining the ultimate power to suspend or revoke a licence.''

TALK.START.PARA: —The second matter that comes before us is the question of the control of local advertisements. Again, this matter came before the High Court of Australia in the case of Saatchi and Saatchi Compton (Vic.) Pty Limited against the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and Actors Equity of Australia. It was decided originally by His Honour Mr Justice Beaumont on 23 November 1984 and eventually was upheld on appeal in the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia. The essence of this was that the Court held that the Tribunal's powers were powers to fix general standards, that is, standards of decency and standards of taste, but were not to be construed so as to give it power over other things. For instance, in the course of Mr Justice Beaumont's judgment, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In my opinion, the ordinary meaning of `standards' and its context suggest that it is the quality of the product, rather than its quantity, that is the subject matter of the Tribunal's power of determination under s. 100 (4) . . .
He went on:
. . . The Tribunal may regulate the content of the advertised material in terms of its quality in the sense of what is regarded as socially desirable or acceptable.
He continued:

In my opinion, such a direction does not provide `standards' in relation to the televising of advertisements. The provision does no more than restrict the locations at which television advertisements may be produced to sites within Australia. It does not purport to deal in any way with the quality of what may be televised.

The purport of this has been that we have a situation in which the Tribunal has laid down standards about the Australian content of a television commercial so that not more than 20 per cent of the time of the advertisement to be broadcast shall be of non-Australian material. In other words, to give a classic example, if I were an Australian company manufacturing spaghetti and I wanted to make an advertisement showing somebody eating spaghetti in front of the Trevi fountain in Rome, I would have to send an Australian actor and an Australian film crew to Rome to film the commercial. I could not make contact with an agency located in Rome and ask it to film somebody else, using its facilities, in front of the Trevi fountain, and send the film back to me to put on Australian television. I would actually have to send an Australian film crew and an Australian actor to Rome in order to make such an advertisement, given the so-called standards laid down by the Tribunal. The Tribunal noted that a number of problems arise from this. In its 1983-84 annual report at paragraphs 104 to 106 it indicated that the Tribunal was undertaking an investigation into what was called ghost crewing. It noted:

On 30 April 1984 the Tribunal announced that it would conduct a public inquiry into the filming and production of certain British Airways television commercials. This became known as the ghost crewing inquiry.
The Tribunal proposed to investigate inter alia whether four British Airways commercials were produced in conformity with the relevant Television Program Standard.

Frankly, for the Tribunal to be spending as much time as it has in those sorts of inquiries is really seen as fairly nonsensical. To set out the position in more detail, rather than detain the Senate I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article from the Australian of 17 June 1985 headed `Tougher local content laws threaten TV ads'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Tougher local content laws threaten TV ads
The Federal Government is believed to be preparing tough new laws to fill the gaps in the Broadcasting and Television Act covering the local content of television advertising.

The moves could make the local content standards imposed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal even harder for multi-national advertisers to expose their international advertising campaigns on local television.

The Government's move follows the dismissal last week by the Full Bench of Federal Court of an appeal brought by the tribunal over a decision in favour of international advertising agency, Saatchi and Saatchi.
The Full Bench decided in a two-to-one vote on the dismissal, effectively quashing the ABT's advertising standards which state that all television advertisements must be produced in Australa.

The standards proclaim ``such advertisements may include a proportion not exceeding 20 per cent of the duration of the advertisement, pictorial or sound matter which portrays persons, places or events which can not be created in Australia''.
The section of the tribunal's standards is legally no longer valid and foreign advertisements may now be shown on television.
Mr Jim Malone, federal director of the Federation of the Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS), made this point clear after legal advice.

He said that while FACTS, the industry's self-regulatory authority, would continue to support the local content standards ``we will need to review the legal basis on which we administer them following the decision''.
ABT chairman, Mr David Jones, said after the judgement that ``we will have to look at the general effects of the decision for a few days before making a statement''.
Both believe the Government would probably move to cover the loophole during the Budget session of Federal Parliament, although amendments may not be effectively in place for several months.

A source close to Saatchi and Saatchi Compton said the agency may have done itself and the industry a disservice as the Government's amendments to the Act could be stronger than the ABT's original standards.

The client at the centre of the row has been British Airways which is working under Saatchi and Saatchi Compton's ``global marketing strategy'' meaning one campaign would spread across many countries.
The airline is not expected to introduce its overseas advertisements in the short term as a result of the court success, partly because of the Government's intentions to close the loopholes.
This would appear to be the case with Coca-Cola, which incidentally will soon be shooting in Australia for footage to be used in overseas campaigns.
It is understood the company and its agency, McCann Erickson, were investigating an avenue where overseas produced commercials would be screened as a ``trade off'' for the local shoot.
The industry reaction to the judgement could be summed up with the comments of Mr Malcolm Spry, group managing director of Australia's largest locally owned advertising agency, Monahan Dayman Adams.
He said many foreign companies would start to use their overseas advertisements in preference to local production.

Mr Spry, and the managing director George Patterson in Sydney, Mr Alex Hamill, confirmed there was a growing trend toward ``global marketing'' where multi-nationals use the same advertising strategy and commercials across the world.
However, there would be only a few campaigns which could easily be transported to local screens without changes, Mr Hamill said.
Companies understood to be keen to use their overseas advertising campaigns include several United States computer giants, including Wang, and also cosmetics group Eastee Lauder.
The marketing director at Wang, Mr Steve Chambers, said: ``The decision vindicates our position that no authority should limit our global marketing strategy.''
Wang last year launched two television advertisements in its corporate communications program and bitterly complained that they had to be made in Australia instead of being imported from the US.
Mr Chambers said the company was formulating its budget for the next financial year and overseas advertisements could be a part of future campaigns if the Government did not bring in the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Tribunal, having had its powers restricted by the Saatchi case, noted further in its 1984-85 report that, because the Minister had indicated that he would take steps to overcome this problem, the Tribunal would not take the case further on appeal. It noted that a number of instances had occurred where this problem had arisen before the Tribunal, one instance being an advertisement produced by Young and Rubicam Coudrey Pty Ltd for Volvo and one shown on Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd as a trailer incorporating footage from the American television program Get Smart in an advertisement for Visionhire Aust. Pty Ltd. It was indicated that this was giving the Tribunal problems and the Tribunal has now persuaded the Government to bring down this new set of standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, although we do not oppose the clauses relevant to this, we do believe that this is an indication of a quite unnecessary interference in and restriction on the power of advertisers and individuals to determine how they want their products to be marketed and sold and, in our opinion, it is an indication of the Tribunal getting into a far more regulatory stance than we would like to see.

The final part of this legislation deals with the powers of the Tribunal under section 119 of the Act in terms of what might be described as the Tribunal's disciplinary powers. Clause 12 of the legislation introduces a new section 119, which states:
Where a person has-
(a) presented in a live broadcast the whole or a part of a program; or
(b) passed or selected for broadcasting the whole or a part of a program (being a program that was subsequently broadcast),

in respect of which, or in respect of the broadcasting of which, the program standards were not complied with or this Act was contravened, the Tribunal may, by direction having effect either indefinitely or for a period determined by the Tribunal-
(c) prohibit the person from presenting programs in live broadcasts or passing or selecting programs for broadcasting; or
(d) impose restrictions on the presenting by the person of programs in live broadcasts or on the passing or selecting by the person of programs for broadcasting.

It goes on to describe certain procedures which must be undertaken in terms of notification and hearings. But the key thing to understand about this is that this is a power given to the Tribunal now to say: `We, the Tribunal, will set program standards'. It is not necessarily very easy to get copies of all these program standards out of the Tribunal; they are not as well known publicly as they ought to be. But if a person breaches one of these program standards-leave aside a breach of the Act; we do not object to that-he may be taken off the air by the Broadcasting Tribunal for whatever period it may direct. It may be for an hour, it may be for a day or it may be for the rest of his career. Not only may he be taken off the air but also he may be prevented from undertaking certain activities related to what the Act describes as the passing or selecting of programs. If one looks at the explanatory memorandum one sees, in terms of the lack of clarity in the Act, that were a court to turn to the explanatory memorandum for some sort of guidance in the matter it would find this:
Clause 12 substitutes a new section 119 which empowers the Tribunal to issue directions to a person to prohibit the person from presenting live broadcasts or selecting programs for broadcasting.

In other words, it is not just that he may not participate in live broadcasting; it is that he may not participate in selecting programs for broadcasting. In other words, he might not be able to function as an editor, he might not be able to function as a program controller, or he might not be able to function as a person selecting programs. This goes considerably further than the old provisions of section 119. The old section 119 referred to broadcasts which caused or may have caused offence to a section of the public. It did not refer to the specific standards laid down by the Tribunal in its own program standards. This makes the Tribunal not only the legislator but also the judge, the prosecutor and the sentencing authority. Under those circumstances, in the Committee stage we propose to move an amendment that has been circulated on behalf of the Opposition to leave out the words `the program standards were not complied with or'.
