In other words, we propose to move an amendment that states that only breaches of the Act should be treated in this fashion because the Act is known, it is public and it is generally available. We believe that that should be the test against which people should be judged. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter to me from David Morgan, the Federal Director of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, which sets out the views of that organisation on the proposed changes to section 119.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Chris Puplick,
Parliament House
Canberra
Dear Chris,

Thank you for the opportunity to discuss our concerns about the Government's proposed amendment to s119 of the Broadcasting and Television Act, 1942. The amendment which is contained in the B &T Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), 1985 has been correctly described in the House of Representatives as ``draconian''.
``Restrictions on Participation in Broadcasts

The amended section 119, by its inordinate and unnecessary width, has the potential for the Tribunal to introduce new forms of censorship in that Tribunal has the potential to make orders against a licensee which could effectively prohibit the broadcast of certain matter or the broadcasts by the certain individuals. While the stated objective of the provision was linked with live broadcasts, effectively the new section has the potential of affecting the rights of individuals employed in the broadcasting industry.

The old section 119 provided that where a person has been prosecuted or convicted by a criminal court of ``rendering, passing or selecting for broadcast an item which contained matter which was blasphemous, indecent or obscene . . .'' or which had caused offence to a section of the public the Tribunal could direct that person to refrain from rendering, passing of selecting an item for broadcast for a specified period.

The scope of the new section 119 is not limited to serious enfringements such as blasphemy, indecency and obscenity. Nor does it rely, in the first instance, on a prosecution in a criminal court. It now encompasses non compliance with Program Standards and any contravention of the Act.

It should be noted that the Tribunal would be given a power to prohibit a person indefinitely from passing or selecting programs for broadcasts where that person may have passed or selected a program which had been shown to breach a program standard.

History reveals that the situations to which the Minister referred in his second reading speech, namely, where live broadcasts are involved are extremely rare. It must be presumed therefore that the additional power and wider scope has been deliberately included to enable the Tribunal to take action on matters which were not necessarily referred to by the Minister.

FACTS questions the necessity to create a statutory power which has been potential of threatening the livelihood and future of individuals employed in the television industry, relying on the act of passing or selecting for broadcast material which was found to be a contravention of a Program Standard or the Act. People who pass or select material for broadcast are the employees of the licensee. It is the licensee who is responsible for the supervision and the actions of employees just as it is the licensee who is responsible for the televising of any material passed or selected by its employees.

FACTS submits that if a situation were to arise where such a major concern became evident after proper inquiry that a major concern emerged in respect of a live broadcast it would be a sufficient and simple solution for the tribunal to request a licensee to pre-record any such matter or any such individual. The Minister concedes in his second reading speech that in those circumstances it would be the licensee who would be clearly responsible.
Again, I take this opportunity to thank you for your interest.
Yours sincerely
DAVID MORGAN
Federal Director

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that in particular in relation to section 119, these are absolutely major problems with the administration of the Broadcasting and Television Act. We will therefore move after the second reading stage a motion under Standing Order 196A for the referral of this matter to a committee for further investigation. We do not believe that the delay in establishing the renewed powers of the Tribunal in relation to children's television will do any damage between now and February and we do not believe that the restriction on the production of advertisements will do any damage between now and February. But we do believe that the issues which are raised by proposed new section 119 in clause 12 of this legislation are of sufficient importance that they ought to be investigated. It is our intention to move that motion. Apart from that, I conclude by repeating our general complaint that the way in which the Government is going about making amendments to broadcasting and television legislation is still too ad hoc and too responsive to immediate crises and has not presented a thought-out revision of the Act which, clearly, is long overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Puplick I pay a very great tribute to Mr David Jones for his magnificent work as Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Australian Democrats, unlike the Opposition, will be vigorously supporting the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). While I am paying tributes I would like to pay tribute to the current Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), who I believe is probably the best Minister for Communications that we have had for a long time. Unlike Senator Puplick, the Democrats believe that this legislation is urgent. When I say that it is urgent I mean that it needs to be passed this session. The Democrats would need to have overwhelming reasons to move any amendments to this Bill because, as we know, the House of Representatives, in its customary fashion, has risen early for the year and if the Senate moves an amendment to this Bill it will lie in King's Hall somewhere between the Senate and the House of Representatives chambers. When legislation is in limbo I do not know where it goes. Is it stuck between the legs of King George V and left there until the House of Representatives resumes or where does it go? The point is that if amendments were carried this Bill would not be passed and the amendments in the original Bill would not apply until February.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had some reasonable representations from Ada de Lacy, Executive Director of the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia, and I have received a letter from Barbara Biggins of the Australian Council for Children's Films and Television and a letter from the Australian Children's Television Action Committee imploring me and other political parties to pass this legislation without delay. Therefore, the Australian Democrats would need overwhelming reasons to prevent this Bill being given royal assent. The Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Bill is an essential piece of legislation.

Television has changed the world. In fact, it is a technological phenomenon for which I believe the world, particularly Australia, was not ready socially. We saw it coming but, like many technological advances, we did not prepare our children for it, we did not prepare family life for it and it and it has had a fundamental impact on our philosophy. Television has changed the world and it has changed the way in which we see the world. It took the printing press, which was invented in the sixteenth century, 300 years to have a marked impact on the world or its people. It has taken television less than 30 years to have a massive impact.

School age children in Australia now spend seven hours watching television for every hour that they spend reading. I shall repeat that to emphasise it. Average school age children spend seven times more of their time watching television than they do reading. That indicates how incredibly television has changed our society. Another staggering statistic is that the average school children, during their school lives, will spend 15,000 hours watching television, whereas they will spend only 11,500 hours in school. In other words, they will spend about a quarter more of their time watching television than they will spend listening to teachers in school.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good deal of it inappropriate for them.

—Indeed, a good deal of it is inappropriate and ill-chosen. During their school lives such children will see half a million advertisements. While I am mentioning commercials I pay tribute to the commercial television stations in Australia. By and large, I think they do a magnificent job. In fact, they compare more than favourably with commercial television stations in other parts of the world. But somewhere along the line a most irritating and impertinent phenomenon is being allowed to occur. Why do these television stations allow the advertisements broadcast to be louder than other parts of the programs? I find it impertinent--
—They are not supposed to be. They are supposed to be automatically tuned down.

—I know that they are. I have checked this with the Department of Communications. There is some technical device-Senator Collard, with his great knowledge of technical matters, would know this-which enables the frequencies to be fiddled with so that the advertisements appear louder to the listener. I find it offensive to my young children when they are watching a children's show to have to experience the showing of advertisements that suddenly come through much more loudly than the rest of the program. However, that is by the way. An industry which has that amount of influence over the way we see the world, particularly the way the young see the world, has to be subject to government regulation. I think even the most passionate deregulation-minded person would have to agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: The responsibility for regulation, including the setting of standards, falls on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I should mention that in order to fulfil that responsibility, the Tribunal needs to be adequately staffed, which I believe is not the case at the moment. Until the Saat- chi and Herald-Sun Television cases, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal excerised two crucially important regulatory powers, namely, the ability to set quantitative standards, such as those specifying the amount of Australian content which must be broadcast; and secondly, the right to require children's `C' time programs be shown to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal before they were approved for broadcast. This we refer to as the pre-classification power.

As I understand it, the Opposition puts forward a respectable philosophical point about standards. Opposition members have some objection to which Senator Puplick referred to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal setting the standards. FACTS-the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations-also has that view; it objects to the Tribunal setting standards.

I think there are only two other possibilities. One is total self-regulation. With the media having such an incredible effect on human life, particularly children's lives, there must be regulation. But somewhere along the line the Opposition has seriously suggested that Parliament should set the standards. That at first may look a respectable proposition, but can anybody here imagine a debate on a Bill which sets standards? The mind boggles at the kinds of contributions that would come from all over the place if Parliament were to set the standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —We already do in terms of blasphemy and indecency. That is provided in the law at the moment.

—Indeed we do, and as a former Minister for Customs, I know the difficulty in interpreting even words which have been specifically designated as that. But we have to go that far and I acknowledge Senator Puplick's point, but when one refers to standards, it goes so far beyond just being blasphemous, obscene or offensive. The only group, as I understand it, to oppose pre-classification was FACTS. Its reservations related partly first, to the effect of pre-classification on investment in children's programming-a respectable point of view; secondly, to the fact that the Tribunal's Children's Television Committee lacked the necessary expertise. I think Senator Puplick raised a question mark about the Tribunal's capacity or expertise in this matter. The suggestion put forward by the Film Industry Standing Committee that pre-classification be done at the final draft script stage has been accepted by the Minister. This would seem to answer one of the industry's complaints. The industry's other criticism that the Children's Television Committee lacked expertise and should be replaced by a panel of industry experts does not, I say with respect, impress me too much. Children's television, including the eight hours of children's drama which licensees are required to program each year, is judged against eight age specific criteria. In order to judge whether the program meets the necessary standard, the Committee needs considerable knowledge of the child audience as well as a knowledge of television production. If the industry is objecting to the expertise or lack of it in that Children's Program Committee, let us look at who is on it. I would like Senator Puplick to tell me which group he objects to and where there is no expertise.

—I did not draw attention to their expertise. I said that they were going too far in regulating children's television, not that there was any lack of expertise. That was a criticism made by FACTS, not by me.

—Then I withdraw my comment about Senator Puplick and I accept what he says. Let us look at this Committee. Three of its members are from the television industry. One member is a writer and publisher of children's books. One member is a librarian expert in the area of children's literature, and one member is a child development expert. One member is a mother of children in the age group covered by the Committee's work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal's power to set quantitative standards is particularly necessary if the world we see on television is to be an Australian world. Only 4 per cent of prime time television is taken up with Australian drama. At least 80 per cent of advertisements are Australian, which is some compensation, as advertising has been a training ground for the Australian film industry. In passing, I make the sad comment that we have allowed overseas companies to take over the Australian advertising industry. I have not the figure with me now but over 80 per cent of our advertising industry in Australia is owned overseas. Therefore, it is essential that there is a requirement in legislation forcing television stations to run Australian-made material. I listened carefully to Senator Puplick's complaint about the difficulties of this requirement, and I accept the thrust of his argument. But if we did not have something in the Act as I have indicated we would have nothing but Coca-Cola ads produced in the United States of America and so on. The Australian film industry and industries associated with advertising in Australia would suffer. The power to regulate the amount of Australian content in advertisements was struck down by the Saatchi case and is restored by clauses 4 and 6 of this Bill.

The Opposition, as I understand it, objects to clause 10 which gives the Tribunal the power to reprimand or admonish a licensee for a breach of program standards, and clause 12 which confers on the Tribunal the power to prohibit a person from live broadcasting for breach of program standards. I know that the industry is concerned about these sanctions and, as Senator Puplick will be moving an amendment in Committee, I will reserve my remarks until that stage.

It must be borne in mind that under clause 7, the Tribunal must call an inquiry before imposing any of these sanctions. Clause 8 provides a defence that the breach of standards was, first, due to a reasonable mistake, secondly, due to reasonable reliance on information supplied by others or, thirdly, was beyond the licensee's reasonable control. In addition, a decision that a broadcaster is in breach of section 119 is reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on its merits. It is not possible to rely, as the Opposition wishes to, on self-regulation by the industry, backed up by the ultimate sanction of removing or suspending a broadcaster's licence. What government would even contemplate taking a licence away from Kerry Packer, for example?

I am not suggesting that that would be desirable. I think that he has made a magnificent contribution to media in Australia. It is nonsense to say that we should rely on the ultimate sanction of taking away a broadcaster's licence. The value of a major metropolitan television licence could be measured in hundreds of millions of dollars. Metropolitan television stations last year made an operating profit of $63.6m. Removing or suspending the licence of a major television station is not a realistic, flexible or effective way of enforcing broadcasting standards.

This Bill gives power to admonish and gives the Tribunal power to force that admonition to be broadcast by the offending television licensee. For example, if the television licensee broadcasts something offensive, the Tribunal can say to Channel 7, Channel 9, Channel 10 or whatever it is: `As the first item on your 6.30 news, you will broadcast that the Tribunal has admonished you for doing something offensive'. That seems to be a reasonable sort of penalty. It can suspend a person; it can impose restrictions on a person. In other words, it can say, for example, that a provocative announcer on radio must have a seven-second delay button. How the hell they work those things out still mystifies me. When I am doing a talk-back program, knowing how someone can press a button and delay what I am saying for seven seconds, I am mystified. This sort of precaution can be imposed on a person or a television licensee. Perhaps we can talk a little more about that in detail in Committee. Generally we support the legislation and commend the Government for bringing it in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to delay the passage of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Referral to Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move, pursuant to standing order 196A:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 be referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in February 1986.

The only point I make about this motion is that we believe that delay may allow us to look at some of the significant civil liberties problems which, we believe, arise under the proposed new section 119. We do not believe that it will have any adverse effect on the children's television side of things or on the advertising side of things. For instance, the children's television decision was made on 21 May 1985. I do not believe that there has been any substantial decline in the quality of children's television programs broadcast since May 1985. Another couple of months will not make any difference to the continuation of that decision. The decision on the Saatchi case was handed down on 23 November 1984. For more than a year we do not believe there has been any evidence that Australian airwaves have been flooded by foreign or substandard commercials. I note with great interest Senator Chipp's concern that we will be flooded with American made Coca-Cola commercials. It is curious that he has picked that as an example because, in fact, the Coca-Cola company was so impressed with the standard of Coca-Cola commercials made in Australia that it took a very brilliant young television executive by the name of Kilner Mason from the advertising agency that he worked for in Australia over to the United States to make all of Coca-Cola's advertisements for world-wide distribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have won prizes.

—Indeed, the Australian Coca-Cola advertisements have won international awards. Therefore, we do not believe that another couple of months delay on the children's television side of things or on the commercial side of things will in fact harm Australian television. We believe it will give the Standing Committee time to look at the civil liberties implications of section 119 and that that is an important and worthwhile part of the operation of a Senate committee. I indicate that should the Australian Democrats indicate that they will not support our reference to the Committee we do not propose to divide on the question.

—For reasons I gave in my speech during the second reading debate on the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) the Australian Democrats cannot support the motion. We do not think that there is the concern that Senator Puplick genuinely believes there is. Secondly, we would need overwhelming reasons to delay this legislation because of representations we have had from the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia, the Australian Council for Children's Films and Television and other organisations pleading with the Parliament to pass this legislation with expedition.

—Very briefly, the Government of course will not be accepting the amendment. The principal reasons are: Firstly, this Bill does nothing more than restore to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal the powers it always assumed it had prior to the court's decisions; secondly, the changes in the Bill are consistent with the recommondations of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts August 1985 report and the Administrative Review Council in relation to the enforcement of the standards of ABT procedures. Obviously, of course, if this amendment were accepted the Bill could not be passed in 1985 and would not be passed until well into 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The only remark I make is that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not correct in saying that this Bill does nothing more. It does nothing more in relation to the children's television programs. It does nothing more in relation to the Saatchi case in advertising, but it does a considerable amount more in relation to removing the old section 119 and introducing a new section 119. The Minister simply is in error in saying the Bill does nothing more than re-establish a pre-existing situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the amendment to clause 12 circulated on behalf of the Opposition. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 12, proposed new sub-section 119 (1), leave out `the program standards were not complied with or'.

I will be brief on this matter. The reason for moving this amendment is that we believe that if people are to be punished, as indeed they can under the provisions of section 119, there ought to be a great deal more clarity in terms of what it is they are to be judged against. We do not believe that a contravention of program standards should carry the same weight as contravention of the Act.

I draw attention to the fact that section 119 of the Act has been a live issue. For instance, in February 1979 the Melbourne radio station 3CR was subject to an Australian Broadcasting Tribunal inquiry over some alleged anti-semitic broadcast. Certain restrictions were placed on it. In a subsequent case the Melbourne public broadcasting section 3RRR had its licence renewed in October 1978 for a period of only one year instead of the usual three years, for the simple offence that a volunteer broadcaster had broadcast what was deemed to be an offensive record. The station was punished accordingly. In May 1972 the Broadcasting Tribunal directed that no live interviews with Dave Allen, Peter Cook or Dudley Moore should be broadcast on Australian stations because their language was regarded as causing offence to people. So these three fairly well known and well established international comedians--

TALK.START.PARA: —And very funny ones.

—Indeed, as Senator Chipp said, they are extremely funny people. The Tribunal directed that they were not to be allowed to be featured in live interviews. In December 1974 Mary Hardy was called on to show cause why she should not be put off the air for use of an expletive. In March 1975 Mr Graham Kennedy got into a certain amount of trouble for making certain calls which he indicated were the imitation of a crow. Since then both Ian Chappell and Derryn Hinch have had certain problems with their broadcasting-in one case I think deliberately; and, in the other case, somewhat more accidentally-and with the operations of the Broadcasting Tribunal. After all Ian Chappell was punished for the sort of off the cuff slip that characterises most of the public utterances of the President of the United States, who does not quite know when the microphone is on or when it is not on. Yet Ian Chappell has been subjected to a regime under section 119 which is now proposed by the amendment in the Bill before us to be extended.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that breaches of the Act may in fact form a proper basis for people to have judgement rendered against them and for punishment to be imposed on them. What we do not believe is that the breaches of the program standards, that is to say, the way not in which the Parliament interprets the Act but the way in which the Broadcasting Tribunal interprets the Act, should carry the same weight as the actual principal legislation. We have had trouble finding out what the program standards are in a number of instances. They are not easy to obtain and they are not published in the sort of way that the Act and the Regulations under the Act are published. For instance, one cannot go to the Government Bookshop and obtain a copy of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal program standards in the way in which one can obtain a copy of the Broadcasting Act and the regulations made under that Act. Therefore, people may find themselves in breach of standards which are not well known or which are not standards specifically given the approval of the Parliament or subject to parliamentary approval in the way in which regulations are subject to that approval. We believe that this is an excessive power and that it is one which should not be in the legislation.

Finally, we believe the power is excessive in that it is not just that people can be punished by being taken off the air; they can be punished be being restricted from undertaking other activities. The words in the Act are `passing or selecting programs for broadcasting'. Thus, a whole broadcasting career might be put in jeopardy. The restriction might be for an hour, a day, a month, a year or it might be a permanent ban. Although the decision is reviewable on its merit by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, I put it to the Committee that the sentence is not reviewable in the same way and, secondly, the standards-the touchstones against which one must be tested-are not reviewable by the AAT. More importantly, they are not reviewable by the Parliament. This is an excessive power which should not be in the Act and the Opposition has therefore moved this amendment which I commend to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For reasons that I gave during the second reading debate of the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Bill (No. 2) 1985, the Australian Democrats cannot support the amendment, although we acknowledge that it is a very responsible and proper matter for Senator Puplick to bring up. This is a difficult question. I disagree with Senator Puplick slightly when he said that the amendment goes further than the original one of 1942. We must remember that something like this has been in the Act since 1942. It is interesting to read the way in which the Act of 1942 is more draconian than this one, and that is where I disagree with Senator Puplick. Section 119 of the 1942 Act says:

SPEECH.PARA: Where-
(a) a person is convicted of an offence against the last preceding section or;
(b) the Board has reason to believe that a person-
(i) has rendered for broadcasting or televising an item; or

(ii) has passed or selected for broadcasting or televising an item (being an item broadcast or televised from a broadcasting station or a television station, as the case may be), which has caused or may have caused offence to a section of the public, the Board may call upon that person to show cause . . .

That is draconian. It specifies that an offence may be caused if a person has broadcast an item which has `caused or may have caused offence to a section of the public'. Does that mean that if Channel 7 broadcasts something that is offensive or may be offensive to the League of Rights or to some fundamentalist Moslem group--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Demo- crats.

—Yes, or anyone-the Democrats or even the Liberal Party or whoever. If it is offensive to a section of the public then an offence would have been committed. The current section 119 is less draconian. Admittedly, Senator Puplick quite properly said that it leaves the determination of those standards in the hands of the Tribunal. I agree with him on that. I do not agree with him that it is difficult for a broadcaster, whether it be a radio station or a television station, to obtain a copy of those standards. It might be difficult for Joe Blow to walk in off the street and say `Look here, what are your standards?'; but certainly every radio and television station in Australia is very well informed about those standards.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been given an assurance by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and I would be pleased if the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, would pay us the courtesy of repeating it today. I hope that the Department of Communications has furnished him with the appropriate words from Mr Duffy which Mr Duffy promised me that he would read into this debate in order to give us an assurance that section 119-that is clause 12 of this Bill-is not intended to have the effect of preventing a person who commits an offence as a live broadcaster from participating in any form of broadcasting. I was speaking to Mr Duffy on the telephone this morning and he promised that he would furnish that assurance to Senator Walsh. Section 119 has been in the Act since 1942 and in that time it has never been used in the way in which Senator Puplick fears. The Tribunal could not impose an unreasonable penalty-it cannot under the amended section in any case, because section 119 (2) requires the Tribunal to consider the offence and impose a reasonable penalty. If in any instance the penalty was unreasonable, there is a right of appeal to have the decision reheard by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on its merit. This is a significant safeguard of the rights of broadcasters. For these reasons the Democrats cannot support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not accept the amendment either, for the same sorts of reasons as those Senator Chipp has given. Senator Chipp referred to this matter, but I think it is important that I should repeat it: The proposed control over standards, if you like, in the Bill is a good deal less sweeping than that in the existing Act. The existing Act mentions that `anything that causes offence to the public'--
—Any section of the public.

—Yes, to any section of the public, can result in the offender being put off the air. That will only apply under the new Bill to breaches of the Act or of program standards. The other matter raised by Senator Chipp was about the assurance he had been promised by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). I have a note here from the Minister's office which I trust will cover Senator Chipp's request. It says that normally the licensee has control over the selection of programs to be broadcast. However, in relation to a live broadcast, a particular person has authority to decide which sound and/or pictures go to air. The part of section 119 which deals with the selection of programs is aimed at this sort of situation. The intention is that if a particular person abuses this authority so as to breach standards or the Act, his future participation in the selection of programs where the licensee has no control might be limited. However, this does not affect the preparation of programs where the licensee or the licensee's employees can approve or disapprove of them. The power proposed in section 119 is not a new one. The power to take that sort of action in relation to offensive programs has existed since 1942. Indeed, for these reasons the power is a good deal less sweeping than it was between 1942 and the present.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Puplick's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 November, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Opposition will not oppose the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985 at the second reading stage, I must register our dis- pleasure about the way in which legislation of this magnitude and complexity is being dealt with. Over the last few years I have spoken at some length in the Senate about this practice. At this stage of the debate I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
`, but the Senate-
(a) expresses its deep concern at the burden of costs and diversion of resources caused by excessive regulation that constricts Australian business and blunts its competitive edge;
(b) expresses its deep concern that the apparent quest for certainty in legislation has led to unnecessary complexity and technicality; and
(c) records its view that the entire legislative package which is the subject of the amendments proposed by this Bill needs to be examined as a whole with the objectives of:
(i) lifting from business the burden of unnecessary, confusing and incompetently drafted laws and excessive regulation,
(ii) limiting legislation to essential matters,
(iii) achieving brevity, simplicity and intelligibility with the purpose of making laws as comprehensible as possible to the ordinary intelligent lay reader,
(iv) widening the process of outside consultation, and
(v) streamlining the processes of law making'.

I would like to indicate some of the sorts of problems that we confront with this companies and securities legislation. It amends a series of Acts dealing with companies and securities. The 118-page Bill contains 200 clauses. The explanatory memorandum which has been made available to the Parliament is of 231 pages. Whether that document elucidates the technical problems in the Bill might be another matter. Into the bargain, the Government put down a guillotine to limit debate on this legislation in the House of Representatives. Only 45 minutes was allowed for debate on this massive piece of legislation. The use of the guillotine meant there was no opportunity to debate the Committee stage of the Bill. The amendment which I have just moved was in fact moved and defeated in the House of Representatives.

Despite the fact that the Bill has been sitting on the Senate Notice Paper for some time, the Government has brought on this major piece of legislation for debate late in the morning of the last day of sitting of the current session. I was personally approached by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) yesterday. He expressed his great concern that the legislation should be passed and not delayed. The Opposition has never intended to delay it. As I said, I was personally requested by the Attorney-General not to impede its passage today. He said it was absolutely vital that it be passed so that the Government could abide by the obligations placed upon it under the co-operative arrangements with the States and the Ministerial Council of Commonwealth and State Ministers.

I am detailing these points to get on the record yet again-I do not know how many more times I will have to get it on the record-that it is simply not good enough for such a major package of legislation dealing with companies and securities laws, complicated and detailed as they are, and in many cases, inevitably complicated, to be handled in this way in this Parliament. I am not prepared to buy that, and I have said this before. I know it was the Fraser Government that entered into the scheme, and I had some ministerial responsibility for it for a short time, but I repeat that it is not good enough to take the view that because the Ministerial Council has proposed this piece of legislation, there is nothing the Parliament can do about it. That is simply not the case. Although there are obligations under the scheme--

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop fulminating. You took exactly the same view when you were in government.

—If Senator Evans were to listen to what I am saying he would not make that sort of inane interjection. There is an obligation, as the Attorney-General personally reminded me yesterday, and I accept what he said; I agree with it. He has an obligation under the scheme to put this legislation before the Parliament, and if the Parliament does not pass it then certain consequences may follow. Let us not be intimidated, as the Attorney-General seemed to be, by any likely threats from the States to terminate this scheme. For goodness sake, the States have gained magnificent concessions under this scheme. They will not want to repudiate it. So let us be real politicians for once and stand up for our responsibilities in this Parliament.
—Are you in favour of national legislation?

—If the Minister will listen he might possibly follow the drift of my argument-with effort, I know. My argument which is not a new one-I am only repeating what I have said in this place several times before-is that if this Parliament is dissatisfied with certain aspects of the legislation, even though it has been agreed to by the Ministerial Council, and if we had had proper time to deal with it, the Ministerial Council would have to look at the Parliament's views. The Ministerial Council would have to face the question of whether or not it was prepared to accept the views of this Parliament. If it was not, that may be the end of the scheme; I do not believe for one minute that it would be.

SPEECH.PARA: The overwhelming probability is that if this Parliament were insisting on a particular amendment to the legislation, the Ministerial Council would accept our views. Yet time after time the Minister comes in here and says that there is nothing that can be done about it. Despite the fact that we are the national Parliament, despite the fact that the Minister has a fundmental responsibility to this Parliament, despite the fact that we have the ultimate responsibility for the good government of this nation and the welfare of the business community, we are being told that we are not able to do anything about it. We simply have to rubber stamp what the Ministerial Council does.

I am well aware that there is great concern about the co-operative scheme itself. I am well aware that many people think it is a mistake and that there ought simply to be a national scheme. I am not going to debate that today. I am trying to make this co-operative scheme work better. The present view of the Opposition on this scheme is that it ought to be able to work better than it does, and it may well be that it ought to be reviewed. We are in the process of reviewing all our policies and, no doubt, that is one policy we will be reviewing. I am not debating that issue today; I am debating this legislation and I am simply saying that the way this Government approaches the question is not good enough.

We should consider further that this Bill is an annual Bill. In fact, I think it is a biannual Bill now; we seem to be getting two of these Bills a year. Certainly, there are exposure drafts and amendments made as a result of the exposure drafts. I am all in favour of such drafts. I said earlier today that it was time the Government gave us an exposure draft on its resource rent tax. I commend the approach that has been taken in relation to this legislation. That exposure draft is for the business community and other interested people, but that does not relieve us as legislators of our responsibility of having to say yea or nay to the final result, which is the legislation presented to this Parliament.

I have suggested, and I reiterate, that this Parliament should set up a standing committee on companies and securities. Because it is essentially a review process, it would be a Senate committee and it would comprise senators with an interest in and a knowledge of, or they would obtain a knowledge of, these technical matters. At least in that way there would be some contribution to this major responsibility of the national Parliament.

There could be no greater abdication of our responsibility than the sorry history I have just detailed of the way this piece of legislation is being processed through the Parliament in this session. Today, right at the very end of the session, I am under pressure to keep my remarks as short as possible because there are still a number of other Bills that have to be passed today before the Senate rises late this afternoon. That is simply not good enough. I propose to keep on making these complaints as long as I have the responsibility of handling this legislation on behalf of the Opposition in the Senate. As I said, this legislation seems to be biannual; it might even be triannual next year. As far as I can see, it will go up at an exponential rate. Once we have hugely complicated, detailed legislation such as this, the need develops for more and more amendments to it.

My learned colleague Mr Spender, who dealt with this matter in another place, indicated that the Opposition was opposed to a number of clauses in the Bill. He gave reasons for that opposition, and I do not propose to go over them again here. On behalf of the Opposition I have just moved an amendment in principle to the motion for the second reading, and we propose to press that view in this debate. However, as we all know, that will not amend the legislation. I do not propose to move or to debate amendments in Committee, but I want to put on record the fact that the Opposition is opposed to 15 clauses in the Bill. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the various clauses or sub-clauses of the Bill which we oppose. As Senator Gareth Evans has not seen the table, perhaps he would like to do so, but I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
(1) Clause 6, page 6, lines 1-9, omit paragraph (b).
(2) Clause 9-Opposition to oppose.
(3) Clause 34-Opposition to oppose.
(4) Clause 35-Opposition to oppose.
(5) Clause 55-Opposition to oppose.
(6) Clause 66-Opposition to oppose.
(7) Clause 72-Opposition to oppose.
(8) Clause 73-Opposition to oppose.
(9) Clause 74-Opposition to oppose.
(10) Clause 75-Opposition to oppose.
(11) Clause 94-Opposition to oppose.
(12) Clause 105-Opposition to oppose.
(13) Clause 168, page 102, lines 3-18, omit paragraphs (a), (b) and (c).
(14) Clause 170-Opposition to oppose.
(15) Clause 191-Opposition to oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —That approach is in accord with the stance we took in the other place, where the Bill was introduced and where the fullest debate should have occurred on all these matters, but, after only 45 minutes, the Opposition was cut off from doing anything about it because of the use of the guillotine. Mr Spender did all he could and tabled the list of the clauses that the Opposition was opposing in the other place. I do not want to delay the passage of this Bill, because I share the concern of the Attorney-General, which he expressed to me yesterday. If we were to debate the 15 clauses, the Bill simply would not go through the Parliament today because the Parliament is getting up. We are again hamstrung from doing anything effective about this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Opposition certainly does not want the legislation to be defeated or delayed. The fact is, if it had been brought on at an appropriate time, some more rational debate might have been able to be had about it in this chamber. Certainly as the House of review we ought to have more time than the House of Representatives was given. Although we do not have a guillotine in force today, we have the pressure of time, this being the last few hours of the sittings of the Senate during the Budget session.

I simply want to put on record the Opposition's dissatisfaction, at the very least, with 15 clauses of this legislation, massive as it is, and reiterate the need for a different approach to handling this sort of legislation. I believe that a great deal of the Bills that are at least annual, and a great deal of the material that is put up through the process of the ministerial council and ultimately through this Parliament, are unnecessary. My learned friend's comments in another place have indicated some examples of where we believe that this legislation is unnecessary. In fact, there is not much good to be seen in it at all and indeed a lot of it is unnecessary.

However, I commend one particular provision in this legislation; the proposal for the removal of retirement villages from the ambit of this scheme. It was discovered that, because of the sort of complexity which I have mentioned, the proposals which are put forward under which people invest money in retirement villages were treated as a prospectus and had to comply with all the elaborate paraphernalia of this scheme. Last year there was widespread concern among the trustees of charitable bodies and other organisations which run retirement schemes. They were protesting strongly about it at that time. As shadow Attorney-General, I told them that we were opposed to that and certainly, if elected to government, we would remove it. I am pleased that the present Attorney-General obviously has made the same decision and in this legislation has excluded retirement villages from having those requirements imposed on them. I commend him for that; it is a very good approach. I commend to him that he should follow that approach in respect of a whole lot of other proposals that he finds being put up to him through the processes of the Ministerial Council and his own advisers.

However, there are a number of other things in this proposal which increase regulation, instead of decrease regulation, to the tune of 200 clauses in the Bill and the promise of plenty more to come in the coming year. That is a happy thought for the new year. I hope that the Attorney-General and the Government will be able to do better next year than they have done in the past couple of years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be opposing this piece of legislation, although I would like to take up a comment of Senator Durack about the difficulty in which this Senate finds itself regularly at the end of the session when the House of Representatives is up and we are faced with Bills of one sort or another which may be more or less imperfect and which may benefit from amendments of one sort or another. We are prevented from doing that simply because, if the legislation does not get through, the Bill will not come into force until some months later when the House of Representatives resumes sitting. I can recall us complaining about this under previous governments and I would have thought that any political party which had the nous to get into government also would have the nous to arrange its business in such a way that this kind of mess occurred less regularly instead of more regularly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985 arises, as has already been said by Senator Durack, from the Commonwealth's obligations under the formal agreement reached by the States and the Commonwealth in 1978-an agreement and arrangement that was implemented under a previous Liberal Government. The agreement provides the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth-States scheme for uniform laws with regard to companies and the securities industry. In accordance with the agreement, this legislation has been agreed to by the ministerial council, which does not appear to have met with a great deal of approval from Senator Durack. Nevertheless, it has been agreed to by the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities. If it is passed, it will automatically amend corresponding State legislation. I suggest that that was at least part of the reason for both Senator Durack's and my concern about being forced to pass this legislation willy-nilly because it has come before us when the House of Representatives is not in a position to accept any Senate-originating amendments.

The first exposure draft was released, I understand, in June of last year. There was, as usual, some considerable response to the draft that was brought down by the Government; indeed, that is why drafts are brought down. Changes were made as a consequence of those responses and a second draft was issued in June of this year. In addition, I understand that a number of seminars were held at which the legislation was discussed. So to argue that there has been no consultation or very limited consultation falls down in the face of that sort of seminar and draft process.

When this Bill was being debated in the House of Representatives a number of members of the Opposition babbled on, as they have a tendency to do, about how there is too much regulation involved right across the board. They objected to a number of aspects, such as the takeover provisions, the investigative powers granted to the National Companies and Securities Commission, disclosure of the basis on which shares are held and provisions affecting winding up. The complaint about the fact that we as a country are becoming excessively regulated is one that I hear regularly when I talk to and meet with people not only in the business area but also in other areas in the community. The attitude of people to having regulations imposed on them seems to me to be remarkably similar to the attitude of people to tax reform. They have a tendency to get up and say that there are all sorts of problems, but they still want their own particular concessions, protections and so on built into the legislation; it is everyone else who is supposed to be prepared to give ground. It is an unfortunate `protect me only' syndrome that is creeping into the community at all levels which I see as I talk to groups. I hope fervently that it is a very temporary measure indeed, because it is extremely selfish and expensive to the community to the extent that vested interest groups are pushing their own barrow and their own obvious selfish interests to a much greater extent now than ever before.

The Liberals have brought forward a fairly long amendment, which is an attachment to the second reading motion, but, as Senator Durack pointed out, it will not hold up the passage of this legislation. They express a number of concerns in that amendment to which I will come in a moment, but they do not seem to have raised-I would have thought that this was at least as important as some of the things they mentioned in their amendment and some of the things that were raised in debate in another place-the point that it is increasingly recognised across the board that there are problems which need to be solved and that many of these problems flow from unregulated corporate behaviour.

One thing that has concerned many people recently has been the spate of takeover activity, particularly in the retail sector, and the broad economic effects of that. Monopolies are not necessarily a good thing. It does not seem to matter whether they are government monopolies, or monopolies in the private sector. They inevitably limit choice and, inevitably, there is a consequential limiting of cost containment. The consumers, ordinary Australians, and indeed other businesses do not necessarily benefit from that. I know that there is a lot of carry on about the benefits of takeovers. People say that they remove weak management, keep other management on their toes and help the economy by re-allocating resources in ways that will produce long term benefits and so on. But, as I understand it, most of the evidence from overseas refutes those rather wonderful claims for takeovers and indicates that, the benefits that are supposed to accrue from takeovers, willy-nilly, very rarely do.

The Liberals, as I said earlier, were behind the formation of this legislation in 1978. Indeed, Senator Durack has acknowledged that. I would have thought that it was, in fact, a useful way for ongoing review to be conducted in this field. Senator Durack has proposed the establishment of a committee to take over this review role. That may or may not be an adequate substitute. It is something that certainly we will be prepared to look at in the new year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am only suggesting it as an addition, as a way of this Parliament performing its role. I am not substituting the Ministerial Council. I am simply saying that this Parliament should have control.
—Are we having a review of the Ministerial Council?
—We are the elected persons in this country.

—That is indeed true. It may, as I said, be a useful alternative or adjunct. I have not seen the fine details of what Senator Durack proposes, but we will, of course, look at it. I just wonder how much larger this place has to become before it can accommodate all the committee structures that everybody is talking about.
—I thought we might have to find something for the 12 extra senators to do.

—I am sufficiently well worked now not to require work on any additional committees. It seems to us that there is a genuine need for regulations to control some of the more predatory companies around the place and if, inadvertently, people such as those involved in groups organising retirement villages are picked up in this legislation, surely the answer is to do what has been done under this Bill and that is exclude them as not being particularly relevant to the processes of the legislation. But there is an increasing number of predatory companies and, in order to protect the consumer and smaller sections in the business community, there is a need for regulations of the sort encompassed by this legislation. We cannot support the rather exaggerated claims in the rhetoric that makes up the Opposition's second reading attachment. It is a particularly long attachment which begins by expressing its concern at the burden of costs and diversion of resources caused by excessive regulation which, it alleges, constricts Australian business and blunts its competitive edge.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat a comment that I made a little while ago. I wonder what the Opposition thinks the formation of monopolies does. Certainly, there is no competitive edge; there is no competitiveness at all when takeovers increase to the extent that we have, in essence, a series of monopolistic companies doing much as they please, not necessarily to benefit the consumer or other sections of the business community. It seems to me that, as usual, the Opposition has indicated, in at least the first part of its amendment, that its interest lies mainly with big business and that it is prepared to sacrifice the concerns, needs and competitiveness of the small business community in its concern for larger companies. The Opposition then talks about unnecessary complexity and technicality. Again, as I said a moment ago, if there are problems with things like retirement villages they can be excluded rather than wiping the whole legislation simply because a few people are picked up unnecessarily. I would also have thought that if a few members of the business community, particularly the big business community, behaved with greater responsibility, a greater sense of ethics, we would not need this legislation anyway.

The Opposition's amendment states the Opposition's view that the entire legislative package, which is the subject of the amendment, still needs to be examined as a whole with a number of objectives. The objectives do not, in fact, include the whole question of business ethics, which I suggest a number of people regard as a contradiction in terms, particularly when small businesses have been the subject of one of the more vicious takeover bids that are becoming increasingly common. The objectives that the Opposition lists on the second page of its amendment include things like consultation. I would have thought that in the process from June of last year through to December of this year, there would have been some attempt through seminars and drafts by the Government to ensure that a fairly reasonable, indeed adequate, process of outside consultation was engaged in.

I am not quite sure what the Opposition means by its last objective-that is the streamlining of the processes of law making. I am sure that we would all support that, given the shambles that this place occasionally gets itself into but, on the whole, the Opposition's amendment to this legislation sets out, in essence, to provide untrammelled behaviour patterns for big business and to remove the sort of protection that regulations and legislation supply to consumers and vulnerable small groups. It does not provide a great deal of assistance to either the legislative process or economic development through the business community in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Haines for a very constructive and thoughtful contribution to the debate on the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985, which demonstrates a much better understanding of the principles of the legislation than was evident from the previous Attorney-General, Senator Durack.
—That is only because you agree with me. If you didn't agree with me you wouldn't say that.

—My idea of an agreeable person is one I agree with. The honourable senator is absolutely right. Senator Durack's speech, by contrast, was the kind of cry of pain and distress that we are used to hearing from him whenever he is confronted with something large and complex. It is a cry we heard from him often enough when he was in government when he had the support structure to prop him up; in Opposition it has become even more familiar, although I suppose it is more understandable. I put that to one side and concentrate on the focus of his attack today which was the inappropriateness, in his words, of this Parliament being asked to adopt a take it or leave it approach to the package of amendments which has come to us from the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities. Under the co-operative scheme which was, of course, the brainchild of the Liberal Party of Australia when in government and, in particular, the present Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, as the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the Commonwealth has effectively surrendered its legislative power in favour of legislation agreed to by a majority of the States and the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Opposition does not like that state of affairs it ought to contemplate joining with us, as it should have done years ago, in enacting a single national company law system which would enable this package of legislation to remain completely within the control of the national government. That is as it should be, the Australian Labor Party has traditionally argued, because of the essentially national character of the problems with which the legislation is dealing. The Labor Party did not support the establishment of a scheme in this form. It preferred a national approach but in Government we have been prepared to live with a co-operative scheme for as long as it works and while efforts are being made to improve the national standards and the scheme is able to cope with the increasing demands for uniformity of regulation of the national companies and securities markets.

When one comes to the substance of the legislation, it may well be that the Opposition does have some disagreements with particular aspects of the Bill. It may indeed be that the Government does not regard every last clause of this Bill as ideal. But it is the obvious and inevitable consequence of the structure of the co-operative scheme that the outcome of the deliberations by eight different governments of different political persuasions with local conditions and pressures which differ in some degree-in those circumstances-will be such that compromises will be reached. If one takes the view that Senator Durack seems to be putting to us that it is an appropriate course of action for this Parliament to reject outright legislation or make sweeping and significant amendments to it, the result of that would, of course, simply be to create an impasse as far as the States were concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would it if the Ministerial Council accepted our view?

—The situation would be that the proposal would go back to the Ministerial Council. It would look at it and if it did not like it, we would have a situation where, in terms of the existing co-operative agreement, after the lapse of six months each of the States could go its own way and that would be the end of uniformity as we know it. If Senator Durack thinks that something is to be gained by bluff, brinksmanship and aggressive and sophisticated negotiations of a kind that he no doubt thinks he is capable of but the historical record is otherwise, I simply remind him of the fact that this legislation has already been through a very prolonged process of debate, discussion, consultation and the reaching of compromises between the particular--
—But not in any parliament in Australia.

—You were on the phone and you were not listening to what I was saying. You never listen to what I am saying anyway. You would learn a great deal if you did. The problem is that we are caught in a situation where we have abdicated legislative authority to an extra-parliamentary body. It is a peculiar and unique feature of this legislative scheme. It is a lousy legislative scheme and I fully agree that that is so. We ought to do something about it but as long as we have got it we are stuck with it. It is no good behaving in this quixotic, will-o'-the-wisp, away with the elves and fairies approach that Senator Durack brings to these debates because it has no shred of reality and no shred of substance in terms of what he is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn finally to the long-winded, rambling, but at the end of the day, utterly trivial second reading amendment that Senator Durack has advanced. Again, it is just a general all purpose whinge, rather than any kind of constructive contribution in the national Parliament to the issues with which this Bill is concerned. I take issue with the claims that this legislation imposes excessive regulation and that it is unduly complex or unintelligible, even though I readily acknowledge that no doubt large slabs of it are completely unintelligible to Senator Durack. The truth of the matter is that this Government has adopted a very aggressive deregulatory posture across a whole range of business activity. I will not bore or detain the Senate by spelling out in detail what that has been. I simply remind the Senate, among other things, that in a recent companies amendment Bill we stripped away very substantially the amount of financial and other information which companies are required to include in their annual returns. The commitment is there and any additional regulations that do arise from time-to-time in the context of this kind of legislative package are based on a very careful cost-benefit analysis.

We all aspire finally to the aim of framing legislation which is as brief and simple as possible. However, the hard reality, as much as Senator Durack might fulminate against it, is that this legislation of necessity deals with complex matters and difficult issues of law which it is simply not possible to instil into a few sentences of felicitous language. The state of the law is simply a reflection of the increasingly complicated and sophisticated structures through which business is carried on. It seems only logical if the manner in which modern business is conducted is not immediately intelligible to the ordinary man in the street, the law required to deal with it may not be so either. It is a pursuit of the will-o'-the-wisp, this constant crying of two-bob populists around the place for legislation that is intelligible to the intelligent layman. The intelligent layman would not waste his time propping up beside his bed legislation of this kind and the sooner we recognise that reality the better off we will all be.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 December, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) at the second reading stage, but we believe that a Bill of this kind should be referred to a committee for more detailed examination. It is another example of the problem which is presented to the Parliament by the sort of legislation we have been debating. It is a large piece of housekeeping legislation which makes supposedly technical amendments and no policy amendments to a large range of legislation. The Opposition members who have responsibility for the areas which cover the various aspects of this legislation have studied the Bill as best they can and believe that it falls within the guidelines for a biannual Bill. Nevertheless, we think the best way of dealing with it should be to refer it to a committee for a proper examination.

SPEECH.PARA: There are no other matters in the legislation that I wish to raise. An amendment was moved in the other place to deal with the problems presented by bans on mail to South Africa and the need for this Parliament to discharge its responsibility to its constituents concerning the principle of being able to communicate with South Africa or, indeed, any part of the world which has been violated by union bans for which the Government seems to have no regard. That matter, however, was the subject of a special Bill introduced into the Senate by my colleague Senator Lewis on which we had a full debate at the relevant time. Unfortunately, both the Government and the Australian Democrats opposed that attempt by the Opposition parties to maintain the freedom of communication by Australian people with countries outside Australia against the sort of union strong-arm tactics which were obstructing that freedom and for which the Government did not seem to give a damn. I do not propose to move an amendment in that regard and to have that matter debated again in this chamber. We have already done our best and we failed because of the opposition to that measure by the Government and the Democrats. As I have said, the Opposition will support this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Durack for his support for the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2), even if, again, it was rather grudgingly given. I just mention in response to his suggestion that the measure be referred to a committee for further consideration-I do not know whether he is proposing to move that-that if we did this we would have a situation in which, quite apart from anything else, the extradition legislation would not be amended as is here proposed and any delay in relation to that would, I am advised, set back the negotiation of extradition treaties in a number of countries by at least six months. I do not think that circumstance is anything that this chamber would wish to bring about. I hope that this will be borne in mind in case anybody has the bright idea of moving a reference off to a committee after the Bill has passed the second reading stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Referral to Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move, pursuant to standing order 196A:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) 1985 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in February 1986.

Despite the attempts of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to make his usual threatening and bullying noise about these matters, we are not moved by the assertion, unsupported by any argument or any facts given by him, that the extradition laws which are proposed in the Schedule to this Bill will be delayed for six months. It seems to me like the sort of figure that the former Attorney-General was wont to pull off the top of his head and make by way of assertion.

The statute law miscellaneous provisions legislation from time to time has been used to do all sorts of things. We are always assured by governments that there is nothing of any great substance in it. I remember that on the last occasion that we had statute law miscellaneous provisions legislation before the Parliament there were two areas of quite significant change to the law. There were some 90-odd amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act, which people did not have a chance to look at and consider because of the way in which they were included in the legislation; and the statute law miscellaneous provisions legislation was used to give ratification to a treaty on the protection of Antarctic seals.

This piece of legislation has at least four very substantial areas in the Schedule. It contains amendments to two extradition Acts-the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966 and the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966. These are significant matters which deal with reviews of magistrates' decisions, the surrender of a fugitive and matters which are of considerable significance as far as civil rights and individual liberties are concerned. There are extensive amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 in terms of the delegation of powers to registrars.

For instance, to take one area in which I think a number of honourable senators have had a very close interest over the years, there are very major amendments to the Patents Act 1952. To take just one example of the things put into this omnibus Bill, the amendments to the Patents Act concern one of the most important and significant new developments in patents legislation; namely, the right to patent living organisms. Issues of considerable policy importance are touched upon by that, as well as issues which are of considerable import for the Australian scientific community. There are the ways in which the application of the Chakrabaty decision of the United States Supreme Court might have validity in relation to patent legislation in Australia. We have a Schedule to the Bill which contains virtually three pages of amendments to patents legislation. Those amendments, in the opinion of the Opposition, concern the sorts of things that ought to be very closely looked at. I take from this large omnibus Bill just those four examples of areas where scrutiny by a committee would be of considerable value.
I conclude by reminding all the absent members of the Australian Democrats of their commitment on this matter. I remind them that the policy document of the Australian Democrats, in part, reads:

All government activity should be open to scrutiny by committee, which should also assist Parliament by making members more aware of matters which need to be dealt with. Committees will also provide a specific mechanism to ensure due consideration of any matter brought before Parliament.
Specifically, the Democrats' policy document commits them in these words:
While a Bill is before Parliament it will be scrutinised, clause by clause, including any delegation of power, by the relevant Standing Committee.

We do not accept that this is not a perfect example of a Bill which ought to be looked at in detail. We know that on many occasions there are examples of changes to the law, including changes made to the rights of individual citizens, which are often sneaked through in terms of these sorts of omnibus statute law miscellaneous provisions. As I was saying, and as Senator Harradine will remember, there was the way in which the amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act were made a couple of years ago in this sort of legislation. I think there are some significant issues in terms of the amendments to the Patents Act, to which I have already referred, regarding the patentability of micro-organisms and living organisms. I believe that this is the sort of legislation which is ideally suited to reference to a committee. The reference is for report by the first sitting day in February. We do not accept that it is not possible to go ahead with negotiations with other countries over extradition treaties simply because this piece of legislation is not in place and we regard this legislation as a perfect test case for this sort of thing. On this occasion we shall also be taking the vote on this matter to a division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too believe that this is a matter of great concern. As Senator Puplick mentioned, about this time last year a statute law miscellaneous provisions Bill which made substantial amendments to a number of pieces of legislation was brought into this place. We were told on that occasion by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) that that situation would not occur in future. I do not have the Hansard with me. I think the Minister will remember that. He gave that indication in good faith. Substantial amendments are now being made to the Patents Act in respect of a very important area of biotechnology. We also have substantial amendments indeed to the family law legislation. These amendments provide for delegation of powers to registrars from judges, including the delegation of powers of the Family Court of Australia referred to in proposed new sub-sections (a) to (m), however many that is. Some of those are quite important delegations.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that most honourable senators will not have had time to examine this legislation. As a matter of fact, I saw on the Notice Paper the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) and I recalled the guarantee given by the Minister previously. On that basis, I did not even look at the legislation because I believed that it would be only dotting the i's and crossing the t's. This Bill does not dot i's or cross t's in respect of at least those two matters. I believe that a reference-I am not too sure what the motion is, if Senator Puplick can help me--

TALK.START.PARA: —A reference to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for report in February.
—I think that would be eminently desirable. Nothing would be lost if, in fact, in respect of the other measures the legislation is only dotting the i's and crossing the t's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects very vehemently the suggestions that have been made by Senator Puplick and supported by Senator Harradine, for reasons of his own, that this is an appropriate measure to go to a standing committee for consideration over the recess period. On 30 May 1985 new guidelines were tabled for statute law miscellaneous provisions Bills of this kind in the aftermath of some concern having been expressed by Senator Harradine and others last year that these Bills were gradually assuming the status of catch-all compendiums for a lot of measures of substantive significance that ought otherwise to be dealt with. The Government acknowledged the force of that criticism and has acted accordingly in tabling new guidelines and introducing legislation on this occasion which is squarely in accordance with them.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not go through the detailed substance of those guidelines, except to say that it is my advice and belief that they have been fully observed on this occasion. That means that the matters before us are essentially of a kind which simply ought not to require detailed consideration and detailed, substantive debate. They undoubtedly do require some checklist type consideration. There should have been ample opportunity for that kind of consideration and, indeed, for more detailed consideration to be given to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2). This Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 16 October this year. It is now 6 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't blame us. You mucked up the program.

—No. It has been available for consideration through the resources of the respective party organisations, through Senator Harradine's research operation and through the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. All honourable senators have had ample opportunity to look at this legislation. There might have been ground for the criticism if the legislation had been wheeled into the House of Representatives two days ago, banged through the House of Representatives and then introduced in this chamber. That is not the case. The Bill had been fully available to the respective party organisations and to Senator Harradine so that they could give it such scrutiny as they thought appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Now let me turn to some of the consequences that would flow from the reference in this case. I mentioned this in my initial contribution in the second reading debate. I will repeat it-to take just one example. One of the amendments proposed to the extradition legislation goes to a crucial jurisdictional issue. It applies to sub-section 4 (8) of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act. It concerns the matter of extra-territorial offences committed by nationals of the requesting state. On the basis of advice I was given this morning and which was repeated to me this morning, a few moments ago, by the officers intimately concerned with it, the reality of the matter is that without this amendment the negotiation of a number of treaties-especially two, one with Switzerland, which is currently on the decks, and a second one with Indonesia-will suffer substantial delay.
