PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave-agreed to:
That leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the termination of the sitting this day to the day on which the Senate next meets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

In moving that motion, I take the opportunity to thank honourable senators for their co- operation in achieving the Government's program this week. I cannot say that I bestow those thanks with ecumenical enthusiasm to all senators, but to the Senate as a whole I say `thank you very much' for that. It has enabled the Government's program to be largely implemented as required in this session without the somewhat onerous anticipation of a further week of sitting. I also take this opportunity to wish every senator a happy and successful Christmas and new year and a refreshing break before the battle resumes on 11 February 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) in wishing a happy Christmas to all honourable senators and those who serve in this place. However, I leave with a feeling of deep regret about the Christmas present that was given to us by the Australian Democrats, who have consistently voted against every committee reference over the past week or more and who today gagged us in respect of a committee reference which they sought and on which they voted with the Government. I think that was a very unfortunate end to the session and certainly it will be a day or two before I regain my Christmas cheer. This is not the time to air that further, Mr Deputy President, and I thank you for looking after the chamber in the absence of the President. I extend to the President on behalf of the Opposition our continued good wishes for his speedy recovery. We regret the fact that he has been absent, and we hope that he will have a very cheerful and restful Christmas and an early return to full duties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that my friend Senator Chaney saw fit to make his last speech of the year in the chamber on a discordant note. I defend our actions entirely. We will do virtually anything to stop this most outrageous attack on civil rights in Queensland, brought about by this gerrymander in which a political party can be returned to government with only 35 per cent of the vote. I make no apologies for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish all honourable senators a happy and holy Christmas. I wish the President a speedy recovery. I spoke to him today and I was informed that his reports are very favourable. I want to thank the Clerks for the magnificent service they have given to all honourable senators, particularly to my Party. I also thank their assistants, the Hansard staff, the dining room staff, the attendants and everybody else in this building who makes the difficult life that we lead more agreeable and more efficient. I would also like to express my compliments to you, Mr Deputy President, for the way in which you have conducted this chamber in the absence of the President. You have been impeccable as always. I wish you too a happy and holy Christmas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to express my congratulations and best wishes to everybody. I will not enter the debate on electoral systems, although I am very much tempted to do so. I simply say that I concur with the remarks that were put down by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). This is neither the time nor the place to take that matter further. This place is certainly not a Sunday school forum. It is the national Parliament and things get a little rough at times. Nonetheless, we get an appreciation of each other's qualities across the chamber. In that spirit, I wish not only those on this side of the Senate but also those on the Government benches all the best for the Christmas season and the New Year.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, I thank you for the way you have filled the breach and carried out your duties while the President has been away. I also thank all officers and staff of the Senate for the sacrifices that they make in keeping this place operating. I have already spoken to the President. However, if he is listening to this debate, I certainly wish him all the best from me and from the National Party of Australia. As Senator Chipp has said, all the reports that we get indicate that he is coming along fine. As a matter of fact, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation announced yesterday morning that you, Sir, were taking the Chair because Senator McClelland was ill. The President indicated to me that within five minutes of that announcement being made he had 10 phone calls from his friends wanting to know what was wrong with him. He said: `I feel a bit of a fraud because I am not all that bad'. I said: `Well, Doug, sit back and enjoy it-it is not too often that you get a chance to get looked after and feel as well as you say you are'. Having said that, sir, I extend the best wishes of the National Party to all involved in this place and to my colleagues on both sides of the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like first of all to express my regret that the President, Senator Douglas McClelland, cannot be here today to give you his Christmas greetings. I am sure I am speaking for all senators and Senate staff in sending such greetings to him and our hopes for his early return to the Senate. He assures me that he will be back on duty next week. On his behalf, I would like to thank all of those who make this Senate function-the Temporary Chairmen, the Clerks and staff of the Department of the Senate, the Joint House Department, the Parliamentary Library, Hansard, the parliamentary refreshment rooms, the attendants, the police and security officers and, last but by no means least, the transport officers who not only meticulously arrange our transport but also are an infallible guide to when the Senate is actually going to rise. I thank them all for their efforts and wish them a happy festive season. On their behalf, I thank all honourable senators who have paid tribute to them.

INTERJECT.PARA: One of the frustrations of being Acting President is that one sees debates go by without being able to make any contribution to them. I, like every other senator, always believe my contributions to be especially helpful and incisive. This is my only opportunity to make a speech, and I intend to make full use of it. I did not know what the circumstances would be when I came to make my speech today. As a precaution I prepared two speeches-a short one and a long one. I am finding speech making so pleasant and the atmosphere so festive that I have decided to give both of them-the short one and the long one. I will give honourable senators the short one first-Merry Christmas; and the long one second-Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.
Senate adjourned at 4.25 p.m., until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 11 February 1986, unless otherwise called together in accordance with the resolution passed earlier this day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Are reports of a proposed amalgamation by the Government of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), leading to the end of the SBS as a separate ethnic broadcasting service, accurate; if not, will the Government state what the options are for the future of ethnic broadcasting services for Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has decided to reject a merger of SBS and the ABC and will move to establish the Special Broadcasting Service as an independent statutory authority.
(2) Now that this threshold decision has been resolved the Government will shortly consider the many detailed recommendations of the Connor Report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 5 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is over $2m currently owed to the Commonwealth in overdue air navigation fees.
(2) Have Department of Aviation staff responsible for collection of these moneys failed to act over a period of years.
(3) Do the aircraft concerned continue to fly and use all airways and aerodrome facilities; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At 30 September 1985 overdue air navigationcharges amounted to just under $5m or 3.5 per cent of estimated revenue from Air Navigation Charges in 1985-86.

(2) The Department of Aviation vigorously pursues all outstanding debts, taking debt recovery action including court action where appropriate. I would draw the honourable senator's attention to the Second Reading Speech for the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill 1984 (Hansard of 8 October 1984) in which the Government drew attention to the need to strengthen the Commonwealth's ability to collect air navigation charges. It had become obvious that normal avenues for recovering moneys owed were inadequate, particularly since the Commonwealth for safety reasons is unable to effectively deny access to aviation facilities and services. The Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Act provides the discretionary power to create the statutory lien over an aircraft where other means of recovery have proven unsuccessful. The creation of the lien provides the Commonwealth with a secured claim on such aircraft and the ultimate ability to sell the aircraft to recover the outstanding amounts. This measure is very much a last resort. The liens arrangement provides for a balanced approach which provides the capacity to accommodate general difficulties faced by individual operators within an effective debt recovery procedure. These measures came into effect on 1 July 1985 and preliminary indications suggest that they are being effective.

(3) Aircraft on which air navigation charges are outstanding and perhaps also subject to a statutory lien can continue to use avaition facilities and services. To prevent aircraft using facilities would effectively require the aircraft to be deregistered. Under the Air Navigation Regulations aircraft registration is concerned with the question of safety. However, where aircraft have been subject to the statutory lien for at least 6 months the Air Navigation (Charges) Act provides the discretionary power to deregister the aircraft concerned. This is a measure which would need to be carefully considered when that stage is reached.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Science had representation from the Director of the Antarctic Division for an airstrip to be constructed in the Antarctic for use by Australian expeditioners.
(2) What action does the Government intend taking on the matter.

(3) Will the Government also give consideration to the setting up in Hobart of an emergency facility which can be called on at short notice by any of the bases in the Antarctic Region with such facility having immediate access to a suitable aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For some time the Antarctic Division has been studying ways in which transport could be used to deploy personnel and limited amounts of cargo to Australia's three stations in Antarctica-Casey, Davis and Mawson.
The most recent study on air transport was a review of the various air transport options conducted by the National Materials Handling Bureau (NMHB). The principal findings of the study were that:

The establishment of an airfield at Casey, for operation of intercontinental aircraft to and from Australia is technically feasible but operationally impractical because of the very adverse weather conditions at the site.

A conventional hard-surfaced runway could be constructed at Davis at an estimated capital cost of $48.6m (1984 prices). The relatively favourable weather conditions would enable the reliable and safe operation of commercial-type jet aircraft services from Australia.
Weather conditions at Mawson pose a significant element of risk to personnel, equipment and aircraft and make lengthy delays and a high proportion of aborted flights very likely.

(2) Based on the findings of the NMHB report, the only operationally viable option for providing an air transport system would be to construct a conventional runway at Davis. However, taking account of interest, depreciation and running costs the Davis option represents an annual cost of some $8 to $10m and provides air transport to one station only. The Government recognises the importance of back up systems for emergency transport and would prefer not to have to seek the support of other nations. A projects group within the Antarctic Division is being assembled to examine a range of transport options, including the use of long range helicopters such as those used from ships by the South Africans in emergencies.

(3) The Antarctic Division in Hobart co-ordinates operations from Australia in the event of an emergency at any of the stations. The recent air evacuation from Davis Station was carried out by a special long range ski-equipped Hercules aircraft of the US National Science Foundation. There are no suitable ski- equipped aircraft available in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1985 (Hansard, page 1140) Senator Puplick asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister seen the text of a major address given by the Minister, Mr Duffy, to the Public Conference on the future of Australian Commercial Television on 30 September 1985? I ask whether, in that address, Mr Duffy stated:

``. . . the Government supports networking. We not only accept the ABT observation that `networks and networking are the heart and arteries of the commercial TV system', but we wish to do everything possible to encourage broadcasters to utilise satellite networking techniques . . .''

I note that the word `encourage' is underlined in the Minister's text. Does the Minister accept that this policy is fundamentally incompatible with any policy of localism? Is the Government now formally abandoning the principles laid down in the Oswin Inquiry and its own previous commitment to support of localism in commercial broadcasting?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I did use the words quoted by the honourable senator but he clearly has not understood them. The term `network' has a number of meanings. It can include any of:
Co-operation for promotional purposes to increase audience and revenue by joint advertising of stations.
Co-operation for acquisition of Australian and overseas programs.
Co-operation for program production or distribution.
In like fashion, `localism' can refer to local production, programs of local interest, local ownership or access to stations by local advertisers.

In my speech I specifically mentioned `satellite networking techniques', that is, I was referring to co-operative distribution (or networking) of signals. There is no necessary adverse effect on local production, local content, local ownership, or local access, in distributing signals via a satellite. Adverse effects occur only if control of this satellite distribution system is used as a means of dominating receiving stations. As the Senator will be well aware, The Government which he supported was completely traumatised by the complexities of satellite distribution of signals and unable to come up with any policy at all. He will be pleased to learn that we have not been traumatised and that my previous statements on satellite-related matters-on Satellite Program Services (1983) and Remote Commercial Television Services (1984) will soon be followed by a comprehensive statement setting our policy on future developments for commercial television for the next ten years.

It should also be noted that the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 was recently amended specifically to allow insertion of local program material at individual transmitters, including translators. That is, we have in place a licensing and regulatory framework which both allows broadcasters to provide local programs or advertising and requires them to meet the obligations set by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to provide adequate and comprehensive programming.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 September 1985 (Hansard, page 444) Senator McIntosh asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Arising out of the decision by the Minister for Communications to refuse an application by the Australian Coalition of East Timor for a licence to maintain two-way radio contact with Fretilin in East Timor, is the Minister aware of a report in the National Times of 23-29 August and a letter in the Age of 2 September, claiming that while facilities may exist, it is practically impossible for members of the Australian public, including East Timorese here with relatives in Timor, to ring East Timor?
(2) Can the Minister confirm that there are difficulties in making ordinary telephone communication with East Timor?

(3) If the Indonesian Government is restricting international access to Timor via telecommunications facilities, would this be inconsistent with international practice under the International Telecommunications Union Convention?
(4) Will the Government seek from Indonesia an explanation for these restrictions and consider urging Indonesia to open up telecommunications with East Timor?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) Yes. At the time of my decision in July not to grant a licence to the Australian Coalition for East Timor, testing confirmed the availability of the automatic telex service, and the Indonesian manual assistance operators did not indicate any embargo on telephone connections. The precise date of cessation of telephone services to East Timor has not been able to be determined. Following OTC's enquiries in response to customer complaints, however, the Indonesian authorities advised on 19 August 1985 that, `. . . for the time being, communications from/to Dilli/East Timor is not permitted.' Recent enquiries by OTC to the Indonesian telecommunications administration have confirmed that the telephone communications with East Timor continue to be unavailable.

(3) No. Although Article 23 of the International Telecommuncations Convention states that `Members shall take such steps as may be necessary to ensure the establishment . . . of international telecommunications,' the Preamble to the Convention also recognises `the sovereign right of each country to regulate its telecommunications.'

(4) The Government's support for greater international access to East Timor has been made known directly to the Indonesian authorities on a number of occasions. As telecommunications are a potentially important means of improving access, the Government would hope that such facilities could be made available to the population of the province without undue restriction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General concerned by comments of experts on international terrorism, as quoted in Press reports which indicate that the large quantity of drugs recently seized by officers of the Australian Federal Police may have been supplied by a Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) group operating in the Bekaa Valley in Eastern Lebanon, and who have given evidence before the United States Senate of the potential for drug profits to be used by terrorist groups to destabilise legitimate governments and subordinate democratic processes.
(2) Is the Attorney-General satisfied with the dismissal of such suggestions by Mr Ali Kazak, the PLO's representative in Australia, as ``. . . speculation without evidence''.

(3) Will the Attorney-General be ensuring that the role of the PLO in this matter is fully investigated and if the charges are confirmed, what would be the attitude of the Australian Government towards the office of the PLO which is already established in Australia, and would members of the PLO be permitted to continue to visit Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney- General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I would, of course, be concerned at any suggestion that terrorist groups were financing their operations by trading in narcotics. However, I am advised that the Australian Federal Police has no evidence that the PLO is involved in supplying narcotics for importation to Australia.

I should clarify that Mr Ali Kazak is an Australian citizen. He is not recognised by the Government as a representative of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation, nor does the Government recognise his Palestine Information Office as a PLO office. Any views expressed by Mr Kazak are those of an Australian citizen.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Queensland office of the Human Rights Commission seriously understaffed, given the highly decentralised population of that State and the heavy workload prompted by a lack of comparable equal opportunity/civil liberties legislation at the State level.
(2) Will the Attorney-General review staffing and travel requirements of the Queensland office to ensure maximum protection of human rights in that State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Queensland office of the Human Rights Commission is at present comprised of the following eight persons: the Director, three Conciliation/Community Education Officers, an Aboriginal Field Officer, an Office Manager, and two Commonwealth Employment Program participants (whose employment/training with this office will be completed on 31 December 1985).

In addition two officers of the Queensland Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation (CDEO) who perform related work are located in the Brisbane office of the Human Rights Commission. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill currently before the Parliament provides for the absorption of the work of the National/State CDEOs into Human rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's functions. It is proposed that when that legislation is passed the Queensland Committee officers will become officers of the Commission in its Queensland office.

In most States, arrangements have been made for functions of the Commission to be performed by State authorities. No such arrangements have been made with Queensland and the Commission has therefore established its own office in that State. The allocation of resources to the Queensland office of the Commission is a matter for the Commission to determine, having regard to the overall resources available to it. I am informed by the Commission that, while the Queensland office has a heavy workload (there being on average one new complaint each day), the staff have been able to cope. I am also informed that the Commission has examined its priorities and is unable to provide further resources to its Queensland office. The Commission endeavours to see that the resources of available staff and funds for travel are used in as efficient and effective a manner as is possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 17 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To what extent are confidential records of government departments being destroyed by burial at public rubbish dumps.
(2) Is it a breach of the Australian Archives Act for confidential records to be buried.
(3) When will proper facilities be available in all Commonwealth Offices for the adequate destruction of confidential documents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am unable to respond on behalf of all departments as my Department is responsible for only destruction of its own confidential records. Those records are destroyed only in accordance with methods recommended by the Australian Archives Office i.e. by shredding, pulping or burning. Burial of such material at rubbish dumps is not an acceptable method of disposal.

(2) Records may be destroyed only if authorised under the Archives Act (1983); but the Act does not specify the means of destruction. The destruction of classified records by burial is, however, a breach of the Protective Security Manual.

(3) My Department is adequately supplied with shredders and other required facilities for proper destruction of confidential documents. Again I cannot answer on behalf of other departments, although in some locations we would make these facilities available for use by other departments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum is allocated in the current financial year for hospitality/entertainment which may be expended:
(a) by the Department; and
(b) by each and every statutory authority for which the Minister has responsibility.
(2) What were the guidelines in force as at 1 September 1985 for expenditure from the hospitality/entertainment account of:

(3) Following upon the statement by the Treasurer ``Reform of the Australian Taxation System'' on 19 September 1985 what action is proposed in relation to questions (1) and (2).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions...

(2) (a) and (b) The guidelines in force as at 1 September 1985 for expenditure on hospitality/entertainment are Section 13 of the Finance Directions (Expenditure on Hospitality) and Department of Finance Circular 1981/6 (Expenditure by Officials on Hospitality).

(3) In accordance with Department of Finance Circular 1985/18 (Reform of the Australian Taxation System), all official entertainment expenses incurred on and from 20 September 1985, are being recorded and monitored to ensure that any retrospective tax liability adjustment that may be necessary can be made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 8 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum is allocated in the current financial year for hospitality/entertainment which may be expended:
(a) the Department; and
(b) each and every statutory authority for which the Minister has responsibility.
(2) What were the guidelines in force as at 1 September 1985 for expenditure from the hospitality/entertainment account of:
(a) the Department; and
(b) each and every statutory authority for which the Minister has responsibility.
(3) Following upon the Statement by the Treasurer ``Reform of the Australian Taxation System'' on 19 September 1985 what action is proposed in relation to questions (1) and (2).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The guidelines in force as at 1 September 1985 for expenditure on official entertainment were as stated in Finance Directions 13/1 and 13/2, and Guidelines 13/1 to 13/14.
(3) Official entertainment expenses are being recorded and monitored so that when the rules governing the liability for the new tax are settled, the necessary transfer of funds to revenue can occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum is allocated in the current financial year for hospitality/entertainment which may be expended:
(a) by the Department; and
(b) by each and every Statutory Authority for which the Minister has responsibility.
(2) What were the guidelines in force as at 1 September 1985 for expenditure from the hospitality/entertainment account of:
(a) the Department; and
(b) each and every Statutory Authority for which the Minister has responsibility.
(3) Following upon the Statement by the Treasurer `Reform of the Australian Taxation System' on 19 September 1985 what action is proposed in relation to questions 1 and 2.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) $3,000. This includes provision for the office of the Commissioner for Commonwealth Government Employees Compensation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 October:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government acknowledge that there has been a decrease in real terms in the level of overseas aid in the 1985-86 Budget.

(2) How does the Government reconcile its stated objective of 0.7 per cent of GNP for overseas aid with the fact that for the second year in a row the Government has moved further away from that target.
(3) Will the Government give an assurance that this negative trend will not continue next financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The level of overseas aid provided for in the 1985-86 Budget represents a decrease of about 5% in real terms over the level of overseas aid provided in 1984-85.

(2) and (3) In my ministerial statement to the Parliament on 28 November, I confirmed that the Government continues to accept the commitment to work towards achieving the allocation of 0.7 per cent of gross national product (GNP) on official development assistance (ODA), despite the fact that we are enduring highly sensitive economic circumstances. I also emphasised the Government's overriding commitment to responsible domestic economic management and the inescapable need, in these economic circumstances, to keep Australia's overseas aid program within stringent limits. For these reasons, the aid program, in ODA/GNP terms, has suffered a decline in the past two financial years.

Nevertheless, as I also announced to Parliament, the Government recently decided that the real level of overseas aid would rise each year in future. In implementing its decision in the context of annual budgets, the Government will take into account both the needs of developing countries and Australia's own economic circumstances and capacity to assist.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 November 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Council of Furniture Manufacturers concerned that imported furniture and bedding is being undervalued for duty purposes.
(2) Are small business furniture manufacturers unable to compete with importers who under-value their products.

(3) Has it been suggested that overseas furniture manufacturers advise prospective customers that double invoicing arrangements can be entered into, thus minimising import duties, any uplift imposts and sales tax.

(4) Has the Assistant Collector, Investigations, of the Australian Customs Service, Western Australia, contacted the Western Australian Guild of Furniture Manufacturers to obtain further details of the alleged undervaluations; if so, are investigations taking place with a view to protecting the Australian furniture manufacturers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Australian Council of Furniture Manufacturers has written to the Australian Customs Service expressing concern over the stated values of imported furniture.
(2) Competition from furniture imports, which enter Australia at unrealistically low prices, could cause injury to both small and large Australian manufacturers of furniture.

The effect of the entry of undervalued imports is that the Government's intentions regarding the appropriate level of tariff assistance are undermined and the assistance provided by the tariff may be perceived to be inadequate.
Of course anti-dumping legislation exists to help Australian producers to compete with goods which are exported at less than their normal value.
This legislation has recently been revised by the Government to ensure that prompt action can be taken against dumped imports, which cause injury to Australian producers.

(3) Yes, it has been suggested that foreign visitors to overseas furniture exhibitions have been told by exhibiting furniture manufacturers that double invoicing arrangements can be entered into, thus minimising import duties, any uplift imposts and sales tax in Australia. However, that suggestion is hearsay only, and has not been verified.

(4) The Western Australian Guild of Furniture Manufacturers has been visited by Customs and certain information obtained. The information was of a background nature and no actual evidence was produced to support action against any particular importers or suppliers. In the normal processing of Customs import documentation, some monitoring of furniture values is being undertaken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Esmond Mooseek disappear while on bail in Victoria during committal hearings on serious drug trafficking charges against him.
(2) Were these charges laid after 2 years of intensive investigation by the Customs Department and the Federal and Victorian police.
(3) Did the police fear the Esmond Mooseek would abscond and sought to have his bail revoked on more than one occasion.

(4) Will the Attorney-General undertake to discuss uniformity in laws affecting bail and the need for greater stringency of conditions under which bail is granted, with his State and Territory counterparts, as a matter of urgency to avoid a repetition of these circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney- General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Committal proceedings in relation to a number of drug offences, including offences concerning trafficking, commenced against Esmond Mooseek on 18 October 1985. Mr Mooseek disappeared at approximately 8.00 p.m. on 30 October 1985 before those proceedings had been completed.
(2) Esmond Mooseek was charged on 27 November 1984 after approximately 2 years of investigation by a joint Australian Federal Police and Victoria Police operation.

(3) Mr Mooseek was initially released on bail in November 1984 after being charged. It is important to note that at that time the police did not oppose bail. On 4 July 1985 he was arrested pursuant to section 24 of the Bail Act of Victoria for breaking a condition of his bail concerning his residence and for the failure of his surety in that his wife sold a house property. A successful application by the Director of Public Pros- ecutions was made to have bail revoked in view of the breach of these conditions and because the police were concerned that Mooseek might abscond. However, despite the opposition of the Director of Public Prosecutions, fresh bail was then granted by the presiding stipendiary magistrate, on conditions that were somewhat more stringent than those applying previously. These included-
that he surrender all passports and not apply for any further passports;
that he not leave the State of Victoria;
that he reside at a particular address in Melbourne, and report to a specified police station on each of three days per week.

On the advice of counsel, that there was doubt as to the prospects of success, the Director did not seek a review by the Supreme Court of Victoria of the magistrate's decision. On 18 October 1985, the first day of the committal proceedings, and again on 24 October 1985 the Director unsuccessfully sought to have Mooseek's bail revoked.

(4) Legislation concerning bail and other matters of criminal procedure is primarily the responsibility of the State and Northern Territory governments. The Attorney-General will decide shortly, after considering all relevant matters, whether to raise for the consider- ation of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General the desirability of having uniformity in laws affecting bail and whether there is a need for greater stringency of conditions under which bail is granted. In this regard it is noted that a report by the New South Wales Bureau of Crime Statistics on a survey of the extent to which bail conditions are adhered to by persons charged in New South Wales with drug-related offences, including offences under Commonwealth legislation, is expected to be presented to the New South Wales Government and made available to the Commonwealth Government in January 1986.

It should be borne in mind that unless the granting of bail to persons charged with specified drug offences were prohibited the existence of uniform legislation would not, of itself, result in uniform decisions being made by police and members of the judiciary, who have the discretion to grant bail. In Victoria there are no offences for which bail is unavailable, although a grant of bail may necessitate the making of an application to a Supreme Court Judge in cases such as murder or treason and is made only in exceptional circumstances in those cases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 7 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many requests has the Australian Government received from Interpol to supply information during the financial years from July 1980 to June 1985.
(2) What was the basic nature of these requests and was the information supplied:
(a) to Interpol; or
(b) to any Government or its representatives relating to the activities or personal information in respect to any Australian citizen.
(3) Who is responsible in Australia for checking any information and facts given to Interpol.
(4) To what extent are facts and other details checked before they are given to Interpol.
(5) Does the Attorney-General or the Prime Minister monitor information that is given to Interpol.
(6) How many requests has the Government made to Interpol during the financial years July 1980 to June 1985.
(7) What was the basic nature of these requests and to what extent were they answered by Interpol.
(8) Who currently represents Australia on the board of management or controlling body of Interpol.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian National Central Bureau of the International Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol) received 24,878 requests from the National Central Bureau of Member Nations during the period July 1980 to June 1985.
(2) (a) and (b) Interpol's aims are outlined in Article 2 of the Constitution and are:

(i) To ensure and promote the widest possible mutual assistance between all criminal police authorities within the limits of the laws existing in the different countries and in the spirit of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights;
(ii) To establish and develop all institutions likely to contribute effectively to the prevention and suppression of ordinary law crimes.

Article 3 provides restrictions on matters to be handled by Interpol. It is strictly forbidden for the Organisation to undertake any intervention or activities of a political, military, religious or racial character.
All requests were in accordance with the Constitution and information, if available, was supplied to the National Central Bureau of member nations.

(3) Where information is requested from an Australian authority, that authority has the responsibility of ensuring its correctness and the appropriateness of its dissemination. The Head of the Australian National Central Bureau must also be satisified that any information or facts provided to other National Central Bureaus falls within the guidelines of the Interpol Constitution.

(4) The supplying authority of any information which has been requested by the Australian National Central Bureau is responsible for its accuracy. The staff of the Australian National Central Bureau then ensure that the information supplied may be disseminated under the terms of the Constitution.

(5) No. The Commissioner, Australian Federal Police, is responsible for the administration of the Australian National Central Bureau of Interpol. The bureau is staffed by members of the Australian Federal Police and the Commissioner is briefed on individual operational matters where necessary.
(6) The Australian National Central Bureau received 27,935 requests from Australian Police and Government Authorities seeking advice from member nations during the period July 1980 to June 1985.

(7) The requests complied with Article 2 of the Interpol Constitution and were within the limits of the laws existing in the different countries. The information, if available, was supplied to the Australian National Central Bureau by member nations for dissemination to the requesting body.
(8) The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Major General R. A. Grey AO, DSO, is the Australian Representative to the International Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did any Ministers of the Australian Government, who visited Singapore between 28 February 1968 and 8 March 1971, complain formally to the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign affairs, or senior officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra, that staff of the Australian High Commission in Singapore rendered unsatisfactory or inadequate service during visits to that city; if so, what was the nature of the complaints, and to what specific incidents did they relate.
(2) What action was taken in response to any such complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Foreign Affairs has no record of any formal complaints by Ministers of the Australian Government who visited Singapore between 28 February 1968 and 8 March 1971 of unsatisfactory or inadequate service by the staff of the High Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action is being taken to implement the following amendments to the Governor-General's Act as requested in a petition tabled in the Senate on 11 November 1981:
(a) that section 4 of the Act be amended to prevent the indefinite transportability of pensions, and
(b) that a work test and a means test be applied to vice-regal pensioners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Special Minister of State investigate the allegations referred to in the Illawarra Mercury of 9 November 1985 that, because the ALP's Cunningham Federal Electorate Conference was `broke' and could not afford the stamps, the Minister for Housing, Mr Stewart West financed and distributed by mail from his parliamentary office in Wollongong a letter to 800 members of the Australian Labor Party in the Wollongong area outlining the reasons for the recent three months suspension of Mr Rex Connor Junior from the Labor Party, to establish whether stamps and stationery provided to Mr West for parliamentary purposes, were in fact diverted for use by the Minister to further the left faction's case in an internal Labor Party dispute against the right faction involving branch stacking and rule breaches.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: When does the Attorney-General expect the fisheries section of the off-shore constitutional settlement or at least the Victorian/Tasmanian portion of it, will be enacted in view of the opposition to the re-opening of the scallop beds off the north-east coast of Tasmania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth legislation giving effect to the fisheries elements of the `off-shore constitutional settlement' contained in the Fisheries Amendment Act 1980 entered into force on 14 February 1983. That legislation makes provision for joint Commonwealth/State authorities and authorises arrangements with the States for joint authorities, the Commonwealth or individual States to have the management of particular fisheries. The legislation has no application to specific fisheries unless and until arrangements covering those fisheries are negotiated between the Commonwealth Government and relevant State Governments. So far as the Commonwealth is concerned, negotiation of such arrangements is a matter for the Minister for Primary Industry. I understand negotiations are under way between the Commonwealth, Victoria and Tasmania in relation to the scallop beds off the north east coast of Tasmania.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the total level of aid provided by the Federal Government to the victims of the volcanic eruption in Armero, Colombia, South America.

(2) What are the Federal Government's guidelines for fixing financial amounts and the basis for decision making on the type and style of aid for foreign countries unfortunate enough to be involved in disaster situations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 18 November 1985, the Prime Minister announced that Australia would provide $2 million towards emergency relief operations following the volcanic eruption in Colombia.

(2) The Government bases its decisions on the level and nature of disaster relief to be provided on factors such as the location and magnitude of the devastation, the humanitarian requirements, responses of other donors, the potential effect of providing aid on Australia's relationship with the country affected, and the nature of the response which Australia is best placed to make keeping in mind the need to ensure that the aid is effective and reaches those for whom it is intended.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 November:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action can be taken by the Australian Government to request the removal of death penalties on Raziyedden Taban, Anoushirvan Lotfi or any member of the Organisation of Iranian People's Fedaian (Majority) or of the People's Party of Iran (Tudeh).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware of reports, including in the most recent report of Amnesty International, of heavy penalties being imposed against members of political opposition parties in Iran. It views such reports with deep concern.

The Australian Government has no direct knowledge of the two specific death penalties referred to by the honourable senator. The Australian Embassy in Tehran has been requested to seek information about these two people.

The Australian Government takes a forthright stand on human rights violations wherever they occur. As a member of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, Australia has supported resolutions expressing concern about human rights issues in Iran and encouraging the Government of Iran to co-operate with United Nations investigatory procedures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs outline the present situation of political prisoners gaoled in East Timor by the Indonesian Government.

(2) Are the results of a fifth inspection of their plight being made by the Red Cross yet available, if so, what are they; and if not, will the Minister make the facts available as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Much of our information on the present situation of political prisoners in East Timor comes from the recent visit of Ambassador Morrison to East Timor. During the visit, the Chairman of the Court in Dili, Judge Siregar, handed him a series of documents which provided the names and personal details of all prisoners tried in East Timor for Fretilin-related offences between 16 December 1983 and 19 August 1985; the sections of the criminal code under which each has been charged; dates of sentence; and details of sentence. Judge Siregar also said that all prisoners on Fretilin-related charges had been tried, while Governor Carrascalao noted that, in addition to this, there might be `three or four' people still in detention awaiting the outcome of investigations before being formally charged or released.

Mr Morrison also visited Comarca prison, where prisoners on Fretilin-related offences are held. He reported that conditions have improved markedly since the new prison in Dili has been opened and is housing all normal civil prisoners. He reported that the more than 100 inmates he saw in Comarca were dressed in clean shirts and T-shirts and shorts, and none showed signs of physical abuse. In making his report, Ambassador Morrison also took account of the access of the ICRC to the prison.

Two other members of the Ambassador's party visited Atauro Island on 10 December 1985. The camp population was made up of 63 people from Manatuto area, 175 from the Same area, and 930 from the Viqueque area. It is planned to resettle those from Manatuto and Same back in their home area in the coming months. There are as yet no plans to resettle those from the Viqueque area.

(2) The ICRC has had access over the past 18 months to detainees in East Timor. The ICRC, however, treats its assessments and recommendations as a matter of confidence between itself and the host government. It does respond to specific inquiries from relatives but does not pass information to other individuals, organisations or governments. My government respects the need of the ICRC for this confidentiality, if its work is to have maximum effect. The ICRC has told the Australian Embassy in Jakarta that it is confident that it has had access to the great majority of prisoners in East Timor. Interviews without witnesses, mail from families abroad and from groups such as Amnesty International provide a good cross-check of information provided by the Indonesian authorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 September 1985 (Hansard, page 507) Senator Knowles asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under what conditions emergency relief can be obtained from the Department of Social Security regional offices.
(2) Can emergency relief be obtained for the payment of fines and court costs?
I undertook to provide an answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question. The following information is now provided:

Agencies distributing Commonwealth emergency relief funds are those which, traditionally, have provided such assistance to those in need. The Commonwealth provides these agencies with guidelines and conditions of grant, which allow agency staff to make their own assessments of client need, and, in no way attempt to impose a Commonwealth definition of such need. Point (a) of the `Conditions of Grant' specifically states: `The grant will be used only for the provision of emergency relief in the form of cash or the provison of a food voucher to a certain value . . .'

It is possible, therefore, that a client could receive cash assistance which might be used to pay fines and/or court costs. Alternatively, a client who has depleted available financial resources, in the payment of such costs, might be provided with cash and/or a food voucher, in such an emergency.

No statistics are available, on the extent to which cash assistance is used, directly or indirectly, to meet fines and court costs. It is unlikely that such statistics could be obtained without impinging upon the autonomy of the voluntary agency, or the right of clients to manage their own affairs to the best of their ability,

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October 1985 (Hansard, pages 1404-5) Senator Baume asked Senator Ryan, who was representing the Minister for Health on that day, a question without notice about the reasons why the Australian Institute of Health and its affiliate, the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine, are excluded from receiving any AIDS research grant money.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Australian Institute of Health is administered by the Commonwealth Department of Health. Therefore its funding requirements are met directly, through the budgetary appropriation process (Division 326). My Department believed it would be administratively inefficient for the activities of the Institute to depend on competitive application for funds through a grant scheme administered by the same Department.

However, I have taken note of the concerns expressed in the Senate on 14 November in relation to this matter, and I have asked the Director of the Institute to invite any of his staff who believe they have a strong case for additional support from the AIDS Research Grants scheme to contact the AIDS Coordinating Unit urgently. The expert committee (chaired by Professor Penington), which I have established to advise on the allocation of research funds, would then examine both the merit of the proposal itself and the question of whether funding from the AIDS Research allocation would be appropriate.
